The polytheists united in their decision not to sit with them, associate with them, trade with them, or enter their homes, until they handed over the Messenger of Allah for killing. They wrote a document to that effect. Banu Hashim remained in their valley for three years, and the affliction, hardship, and hunger intensified upon them. When three years had passed, some men from Quraysh blamed each other for what had happened and agreed to annul the document. Thus, the boycott ended.

title: The Quraysh's breach of the Charter of Medina.
details: After two or three years of the unjust siege in the valley of Abu Talib, the document was annulled and the siege was lifted. This was because the Quraysh were divided between those who were pleased with this pact and those who disliked it. So, those who disliked it sought to annul the document. The one who took the initiative was Hisham ibn Amr from Banu Amer ibn Lu'ayy. He used to secretly supply the Banu Hashim in the valley with food at night. He went to Zuhayr ibn Abi Umayyah al-Makhzumi, whose mother was Atikah bint Abd al-Muttalib, and said: "O Zuhayr, are you content to eat food and drink, while your maternal uncles are in the state you know?" He replied: "Woe to you, what can I do? I am only one man. By God, if I had another man with me, I would stand up to annul it." He said: "You have found a man." He asked: "Who is it?" He replied: "I am." Zuhayr then said to him: "Find us a third man." So, he went to Al-Mu'tim ibn Adi, reminded him of the kinship ties between Banu Hashim and Banu al-Muttalib, sons of Abd Manaf, and blamed him for agreeing with the Quraysh on this injustice. Al-Mu'tim said: "Woe to you, what can I do? I am only one man." He said: "You have found a second." He asked: "Who is it?" He replied: "I am." He said: "Find us a third." He said: "I have done so." He asked: "Who is it?" He replied: "Zuhayr ibn Abi Umayyah." He said: "Find us a fourth." So, he went to Abu al-Bukhtari ibn Hisham and said to him much the same as he had said to Al-Mu'tim. He asked: "Is there anyone who will help with this?" He said: "Yes." He asked: "Who is it?" He replied: "Zuhayr ibn Abi Umayyah, Al-Mu'tim ibn Adi, and I am with you." He said: "Find us a fifth." So, he went to Zam'ah ibn al-Aswad ibn al-Muttalib ibn Asad, spoke to him, and reminded him of their kinship and their rights. He asked him: "Is there anyone else for this matter you are calling me to?" He said: "Yes." Then he named the people to him. They gathered at al-Hajun and pledged to stand up to annul the document. Zuhayr said: "I will start with you, so I will be the first to speak." When morning came, they went to their assemblies. Zuhayr went, wearing a garment, circled the Kaaba seven times, then turned to the people and said: "O people of Mecca, do we eat food and wear clothes while Banu Hashim are perishing, and no one buys from or sells to them? By God, I will not sit down until this cutting and unjust document is torn." Abu Jahl, who was in a corner of the mosque, said: "You lie, by God, it will not be torn." Zam'ah ibn al-Aswad said: "By God, you are the liar. We did not agree to its writing when it was written." Abu al-Bukhtari said: "Zam'ah has spoken the truth. We do not agree with what was written in it, nor do we acknowledge it." Al-Mu'tim ibn Adi said: "You both have spoken the truth, and whoever says otherwise is a liar. We absolve ourselves before God of it and of what was written in it." Hisham ibn Amr said something similar. Abu Jahl then said: "This is a matter decided at night, and discussed elsewhere." Abu Talib was sitting in a corner of the mosque. They came to them because God had informed His Messenger, peace be upon him, about the document and that He had sent the termite upon it, and it had eaten everything in it of injustice, severance, and oppression, except for the mention of God, the Mighty and Majestic. He informed his uncle, who went to the Quraysh and told them that his nephew had said such and such. He said: "If he is lying, we will leave you to deal with him, and if he is telling the truth, you will cease your severance and injustice towards us." They said: "You have been fair." After the discussion between the people and Abu Jahl, Al-Mu'tim stood up to tear the document, and found that the termite had eaten it except for "(In Your Name, O Allah)," and whatever mention of God was in it, it had not eaten. Then the document was annulled, and the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, and those with him, came out of the valley. The polytheists had seen a great sign of his prophethood, but they were as God described them: "(And if they see a sign, they turn away and say, 'This is continuous magic.')" They turned away from this sign and increased their disbelief.

title: The passing of the Mother of the Believers, Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her.
details: She is Khadijah, daughter of Khuwaylid, son of Asad, son of Abd al-Uzza, son of Qusai, son of Kilab, among the best women of this world. Gabriel came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: "O Messenger of Allah, Khadijah has come to you with a vessel containing food, or drink. When she comes to you, convey to her greetings from her Lord and from me, and give her glad tidings of a house in Paradise made of reeds, wherein there will be no noise nor toil." Khadijah was the first to embrace Islam with the Prophet, peace be upon him. She believed in him when people disbelieved, she sheltered him when people rejected him, and she affirmed him when people denied him. Allah blessed him with children through her: Al-Qasim, At-Tayyib, and At-Tahir, who died in infancy, and Ruqayyah, Zaynab, Umm Kulthum, and Fatimah. May Allah be pleased with her. She passed away, along with Abu Talib, in the same year. The calamities followed one another for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, with their deaths. Khadijah was a minister of truth for Islam, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, found solace in her. "Khadijah passed away three years before the Prophet, peace be upon him, migrated to Medina. He remained for two years, or close to that, and married Aisha when she was six years old, and then consummated the marriage when she was nine years old." The Mother of the Believers, Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her, passed away in Mecca and was buried in Al-Hajun.

title: The departure of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to Ta'if.
details: The Prophet, peace be upon him, went out to Taif, which is about sixty miles from Mecca. He walked there and back on foot, accompanied by his freed slave Zayd ibn Harithah. Whenever he passed a tribe on the way, he invited them to Islam, but none responded. When he reached Taif, he approached its leaders and invited them, but they did not respond. He stayed among the people of Taif for ten days, visiting every one of their nobles and speaking to them. They told him, "Leave our land." They incited their fools against him. When he intended to leave, the fools and their slaves followed him, insulting and shouting at him, until the people gathered against him. They formed two lines and began to stone him and hurl insults at him, and they stoned his heels until his sandals were stained with blood. Zayd ibn Harithah protected him with his own body, sustaining a head wound. The fools continued to harass him until they forced him to take refuge in a garden belonging to Utbah and Shaybah, sons of Rabi'ah, three miles from Taif. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, returned on the road to Mecca after leaving the garden, dejected and sorrowful, with a broken heart. When he reached Qarn al-Manazil, God sent Gabriel to him, accompanied by the Angel of the Mountains, asking if he wished to crush the people of Mecca between the two mountains. The Prophet, peace be upon him, replied, "Rather, I hope that God, the Almighty, will bring forth from their loins those who worship God, the Almighty, alone, associating nothing with Him." In this response given by the Messenger, peace be upon him, his unique character and his great moral disposition are evident.

title: The Islam of the Jinn and their coming in delegations to the Prophet, peace be upon him.
details: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, returned from Ta'if to Mecca, he stopped at Nakhlah. In the middle of the night, he rose to pray. The group of jinn, whom Allah the Almighty mentioned, passed by him. They were seven jinn from the people of Nasibin. They listened to the recitation of the Messenger, peace be upon him. When he finished his prayer, they turned back to their people as warners, having believed and responded to what they heard. Regarding them, Allah the Almighty revealed: "And [mention, O Muhammad], when We directed to you a few of the jinn to listen to the Quran. When they attended it, they said, 'Be silent.' And when it was finished, they went back to their people, warning. They said, 'O our people, indeed we have heard a Book revealed after Moses, confirming that which was before it, guiding to the truth and to a straight path. O our people, respond to the one who calls to Allah and believe in him. He will forgive for you your sins and protect you from a painful punishment. And whoever does not respond to the one who calls to Allah will not cause failure on earth, and he will not have besides Him protectors. Those are in clear error.'" [Al-Ahqaf]. And after several months from the meeting of the first delegation of jinn with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the second delegation came, eager to see the beloved chosen one, peace be upon him, and to listen to the words of the Lord of the worlds.

title: The death of Abu Talib, the uncle of the Prophet, peace be upon him.
details: After the illness intensified for Abu Talib, the uncle of the Prophet, peace be upon him, who had taken care of him when he was young, supported him when he was older, aided him in his call, and protected him from the harm of the polytheists, the Prophet, peace be upon him, entered upon him. Abu Jahl was with him. The Prophet said: "O uncle, say: 'There is no god but Allah,' a word for which I will argue on your behalf before Allah." Abu Jahl and Abdullah ibn Abi Umayyah said: "O Abu Talib, do you turn away from the religion of Abdul Muttalib?" They continued to speak to him until the last thing he said to them was: "On the religion of Abdul Muttalib." Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "I will surely ask forgiveness for you as long as I am not forbidden." Then it was revealed: {It is not for the Prophet and those who have believed to ask forgiveness for the polytheists, even if they were relatives, after it has become clear to them that they are companions of the Hellfire.} And it was revealed: {Indeed, you do not guide whom you love.} Abu Talib had been the fortress behind which the Prophet, peace be upon him, took refuge from the attacks of the prominent and the foolish, but he remained upon the religion of the elders among his forefathers, and thus did not succeed.

title: The marriage of the Prophet, peace be upon him, to Sawdah bint Zam'ah, may Allah be pleased with her.
details: After the death of the Mother of the Believers, Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her, who was one of Allah's great blessings upon the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, married Sawdah bint Zam'ah ibn Qays ibn 'Abd Shams ibn 'Abd Wudd ibn Nasr ibn Malik ibn Hisl ibn 'Amir ibn Lu'ayy, al-Qurashiyyah. He married her in Mecca before the Hijra. She was among those who embraced Islam early and migrated the second migration to Abyssinia. Her husband was al-Sakran ibn 'Amr, who had embraced Islam and migrated with her. He died in the land of Abyssinia, or after returning to Mecca. When her waiting period ended, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, proposed to her and married her. She was the first woman he married after the death of Khadijah. She was in her sixth decade of life at that time. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, intended to divorce her, she reconciled with him by gifting her turn to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, so he kept her. She did not bear him any children until he passed away, peace be upon him.

title: The beginning of the Ansar's entry into Islam.
details: When Allah, the Almighty, willed to manifest His religion, honor His Prophet, peace be upon him, and fulfill His promise to him, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went out during the Hajj season, presenting himself to the Arab tribes, as he had done in every season. While he was at Al-Aqabah, he met a group of Khazraj whom Allah intended good for. He asked them, "Who are you?" They replied, "A group of Khazraj." He asked, "Are you allies of the Jews?" They said, "Yes." He then asked, "Will you sit with me so I may speak to you?" They replied, "Certainly." So they sat with him, and he invited them to Allah, the Almighty, presented Islam to them, and recited the Quran to them. Among the favors Allah bestowed upon them in Islam was that the Jews were with them in their land, and they used to warn them of the imminent appearance of a prophet whom they would follow, and then with him, they would kill the Arabs with a decisive victory. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, spoke to them and invited them to Allah, some of them said to each other, "O people, know that, by Allah, this is the prophet whom the Jews warned you about. So do not let them get to him before you." They responded to his invitation and said to him, "We have left our people, and there is no people between us who have as much enmity and conflict as they do. Perhaps Allah will unite them with you. We will return and invite them to your cause, and present to them what we have accepted from this religion. If Allah unites them with you, no man will be more honored than you." Then they departed, returning to their land, having believed and testified. When they arrived in Medina to their people, they spoke of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and invited them to Islam until it spread among them. There was no house among the Ansar that did not have mention of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him.

title: The marriage of the Prophet to Aisha, daughter of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with them both.
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, married Aisha the Truthful, may Allah be pleased with her, when she was six years old, and consummated the marriage with her in Medina in Shawwal in the second year of the Hijra, when she was nine years old. She was the most favored and beloved of his wives to him, and he did not marry any virgin other than her.

title: The First Pledge of al-Aqabah
details: It was narrated from `Ubadah ibn al-Samit, may Allah be pleased with him, one of the chieftains on the night of `Aqabah, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, his family, and his companions, said while a group of his companions were around him: "Pledge allegiance to me on the condition that you will not associate anything with Allah, will not steal, will not commit adultery, will not kill your children, will not utter slander which you have forged between your hands and your feet, and will not disobey in what is right. Whoever among you fulfills this, his reward is with Allah. Whoever commits any of these acts and is punished in this world, it will be an expiation for him. Whoever commits any of these acts and Allah conceals him, then it is up to Allah; if He wills, He will forgive him, and if He wills, He will punish him." He said: "So we pledged allegiance to him on that basis."

title: The Night Journey, the Ascension, and the Obligation of the Five Daily Prayers.
details: In this great incident, the Prophet, peace be upon him, saw the prophets, and saw the Lote tree of the Utmost Boundary, and other great signs. In it, the five daily prayers were ordained, and this is something agreed upon by the narrations of the two Sahih collections. The Quraysh denied the occurrence of the incident of the Night Journey and Ascension, and this is also something agreed upon by the narrations of the two Sahih collections. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "I saw myself in the Hijr, and the Quraysh were asking me about my Night Journey. They asked me about things from Jerusalem that I had not retained. So I was distressed with a distress the like of which I had never experienced." He said: "Then Allah raised it for me to look at. Whatever they asked me about, I informed them. I saw myself in a gathering of prophets. There was Moses, standing and praying. He was a man of strong build, curly-haired, as if from the men of Shinū'ah. And there was Jesus, son of Mary, peace be upon him, standing and praying. The person most resembling him in likeness was Urwah ibn Mas'ud al-Thaqafi. And there was Abraham, peace be upon him, standing and praying. The person most resembling him was your companion" - meaning himself. Then the time for prayer came, and I led them in prayer. When I finished the prayer, someone said: "O Muhammad, this is Malik, the keeper of Hellfire. Greet him." So I turned to him, and he greeted me first."

title: The Hijra of Abu Salamah and Umm Salamah, may Allah be pleased with them.
details: Abu Salamah Abdullah ibn Abd al-Asad was the first of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, among the Emigrants from Quraysh from Banu Makhzum, to migrate to Medina. His migration took place after the first pledge of Aqabah and before the second pledge of Aqabah, when the Quraysh had harmed him after his return from Abyssinia. He resolved to return there, and then it reached him that they had brothers in Medina, so he decided to migrate to them. Umm Salamah said: When Abu Salamah decided to go to Medina, he prepared a camel for me, then placed me upon it, and put my son Salamah ibn Abi Salamah in my lap. Then he went out leading my camel, and the Banu Abd al-Asad went with him, while the Banu Mughirah detained me with them, and my husband Abu Salamah went to Medina. She said: So I was separated from my son and my husband. She said: I used to go out every morning and sit in al-Abṭaḥ, and I would not stop crying until evening, for a year or close to it, until a man from my paternal uncles, one of the Banu Mughirah, passed by me and saw my state and took pity on me. He said to the Banu Mughirah: Will you not release this poor woman? Have you separated her from her husband and her child? She said: They then said to me: Go to your husband if you wish. She said: At that, the Banu Abd al-Asad returned my son to me. She said: So I prepared my camel, then took my son and placed him in my lap, then I set out to go to my husband in Medina. She said: And I had no one from God's creation with me, until when I reached al-Tan'im, I met Uthman ibn Talhah ibn Abi Talhah, brother of Banu Abd al-Dar. He said: Where are you going, O daughter of Umm Ayyah? I said: I am going to my husband in Medina. He said: Do you not have anyone with you? I said: I have no one with me except Allah and this son of mine. He said: By Allah, you are not to be left behind. He took the camel's reins and set out with me, hurrying me along. By Allah, I have never accompanied any man among the Arabs whom I considered more honorable than him. When he reached a stopping place, he would make the camel kneel, then he would move away from me until I dismounted. When I dismounted, he would move his camel away, unload it, then tie it to a tree. Then he would move to a tree and lie down beneath it. When it was time to depart, he would stand by my camel, prepare it, then move away from me and say: Mount. When I mounted and settled on my camel, he would come, take the reins, and lead me until he dismounted me. He continued to do this for me until he brought me to Medina. When he saw the village of Banu Amr ibn Awf in Quba, he said: Your husband is in this village. Abu Salamah was residing there, so enter it with the blessing of Allah. Then he returned to Mecca. Umm Salamah used to say: I do not know of any family in Islam that suffered what the family of Abu Salamah suffered, and I have never seen a companion more honorable than Uthman ibn Talhah. Uthman ibn Talhah ibn Abi Talhah al-Abdari embraced Islam after Hudaybiyyah.

title: The spread of Islam in Yathrib after the First Pledge of Aqabah.
details: After the first Pledge of Aqabah, the Ansar wrote to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, asking him to send someone to lead them in prayer and teach them the Quran. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent them Mus'ab ibn Umayr. He stayed as a guest of Sa'd ibn Zurarah and began to call people to Islam. Islam spread among the people of Yathrib until there was no house in Yathrib that did not have a Muslim man or woman. Among those who embraced Islam at his hands were the two chiefs of the Aws, Sa'd ibn Mu'adh and Usayd ibn Hudayr.

title: The Second Pledge of al-Aqabah.
details: Jabir reported: "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, stayed in Mecca for ten years, approaching people in their dwellings, at 'Ukaz, Majanna, and during the seasons in Mina, saying: 'Who will host me? Who will support me so that I may convey the message of my Lord, and for him shall be Paradise?' It reached the point that a man would come from Yemen or from Muzar, and his people would say to him: 'Beware of the Qurayshite youth, lest he tempt you.' He would walk among their men, and they would point at him with their fingers. Until Allah sent us from Yathrib to him, so we hosted him and believed in him. A man from us would go out, believe in him, and teach him the Quran. Then he would return to his family, and they would embrace Islam with his Islam, until there was no house among the houses of the Ansar but had a group of Muslims openly declaring Islam. Then we all consulted and said: 'How long shall we leave the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to be driven away in the mountains of Mecca and live in fear?' So seventy men from us set out to him, until they met him during the season, and we promised him at the valley of al-'Aqabah. We gathered around him, a man or two at a time, until we were complete. We said: 'O Messenger of Allah, we will pledge allegiance to you.' He said: 'You will pledge allegiance to me on hearing and obeying, in times of eagerness and reluctance, on spending in times of hardship and ease, on enjoining good and forbidding evil, and that you speak the truth about Allah, fearing no blame from any blamer. And that you support me, so you protect me when I come to you, just as you protect yourselves, your wives, and your children, and for you shall be Paradise.' He said: 'So we stood up to him and pledged allegiance. Al-As'ad ibn Zurarah, who was one of the youngest, took his hand and said: 'Hold on, O people of Yathrib. We did not travel on the backs of camels except that we knew he was the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. And his departure today means the separation of all Arabs, the killing of your best men, and that swords will bite you. So if you are people who can endure this, your reward is with Allah. But if you fear weakness in yourselves, then make it clear, and that is an excuse for you with Allah.' They said: 'Remove it from us, O As'ad. By Allah, we will never abandon this pledge, nor will we ever break it.' He said: 'So we stood up to him and pledged allegiance, and he took our pledge and stipulated conditions, and in return for that, he promised us Paradise.'"

title: The miracle of the splitting of the moon.
details: From Abdullah bin Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The moon was split into two parts during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Bear witness." And from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that the people of Mecca asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to show them a sign, so he showed them the moon split into two parts, until they saw Hira between them. And in Sahih Muslim, from Abdullah bin Mas'ud, who said: The moon was split into two halves during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. The mountain covered one half, and one half was above the mountain. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "O Allah, bear witness." It is widely known that the splitting of the moon occurred only once. As for what is mentioned in one of the narrations of Muslim: (...so he showed them the splitting of the moon twice), scholars have responded to it. Ibn al-Qayyim, Ibn Hajar, and others have favored that it occurred only once.

title: The Islam of Abdullah ibn Salam, may Allah be pleased with him.
details: Abdullah ibn Salam, may Allah be pleased with him, was a distinguished scholar among the Jews, a learned man. He said: "When I heard about the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, I recognized his description, his name, and the time we were expecting him. I kept this to myself, remaining silent about it, until the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, arrived in Medina. When he stayed in Quba, among the Banu Amr ibn Awf, a man came and informed me of his arrival. I was at the top of my palm tree, working on it, and my aunt, Khālidah bint al-Ḥārith, was sitting below me. When I heard the news of the Messenger of Allah's arrival, peace and blessings be upon him, I exclaimed 'Allahu Akbar!' My aunt said to me upon hearing my exclamation: 'May Allah disappoint you! By God, if you had heard of Moses son of Imran arriving, you would not have done more!' I said to her: 'O aunt, he is, by God, the brother of Moses son of Imran, and on his religion, he has been sent with what he was sent with.' She said: 'O my nephew, is he the Prophet we were told would be sent with the coming of the Hour?' I said to her: 'Yes.' She said: 'Then that is he.' Then I went out to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and embraced Islam. Then I returned to my household and commanded them, and they embraced Islam. I concealed my Islam from the Jews. Then I came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said to him: 'O Messenger of Allah, the Jews are a deceitful people, and I would like you to admit me into one of your houses, and conceal me from them, and then ask them about me, so that they may tell you what I am like among them, before they know of my Islam. For if they know of it, they will deceive me and criticize me.' So the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, admitted me into one of his houses, and they came to him and spoke with him and questioned him. Then he said to them: 'What kind of man is Abdullah ibn Salam among you?' They said: 'Our master and son of our master, our scholar and learned man.' When they finished speaking, I came out to them and said: 'O assembly of Jews, fear Allah and accept what has come to you. For by God, you know that he is indeed the Messenger of Allah. You find him written among you in the Torah by his name and description. I bear witness that he is the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and I believe in him, and I affirm him, and I recognize him.' They said: 'You lie.' Then they attacked me. I said to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Did I not tell you, O Messenger of Allah, that they are a deceitful people, a people of treachery, lies, and wickedness!' Then I revealed my Islam and the Islam of my household, and my aunt Khālidah bint al-Ḥārith embraced Islam, and her Islam was good."

title: The Prophet's peace be upon him treaty with the Jews.
details: Ibn Ishaq said: "The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, wrote a document between the Emigrants and the Helpers, and in it he made peace with the Jews, covenanted with them, confirmed them in their religion and their property, and stipulated conditions for them and they for him." This was when they refused to follow him, and this was before permission was given to fight and to take the jizya from those who refused Islam. Indeed, the majority of them refused except for disbelief. They were three tribes: Banu Qaynuqa, Banu an-Nadir, and Banu Qurayza. All three fought him. He showed favor to Banu Qaynuqa, exiled Banu an-Nadir, and killed Banu Qurayza, taking their descendants captive. Surah Al-Hashr was revealed concerning Banu an-Nadir, and Surah Al-Ahzab concerning Banu Qurayza.

title: The permissibility of the Adhan.
details: Ibn Umar narrated that when the Muslims arrived in Medina, they used to gather and wait for the prayers, but no one called them to prayer. One day, they discussed this matter. Some of them said, "Let's take a bell like the Christians' bell." Others said, "Let's take a horn like the Jews' horn." Abdullah bin Zayd said: "When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered that a bell be made to strike for people to gather for prayer, a man carrying a bell in his hand passed by me while I was asleep. I said to him, 'O servant of Allah, will you sell the bell?' He asked, 'What will you do with it?' I replied, 'We will call people to prayer with it.' He said, 'Shall I not guide you to something better than that?' I said, 'Yes.' He then said: 'You should say: Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illallah, Ash-hadu an la ilaha illallah. Ash-hadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah, Ash-hadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Hayya 'alas-Salah, Hayya 'alas-Salah. Hayya 'alal-Falah, Hayya 'alal-Falah. Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illallah.' Then he moved a short distance away from me and said: 'And when you commence the prayer, say: Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. Ash-hadu an la ilaha illallah. Ash-hadu anna Muhammadan Rasulullah. Hayya 'alas-Salah. Hayya 'alal-Falah. Qad qamatis-Salah, Qad qamatis-Salah. Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar. La ilaha illallah.'" When morning came, I went to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and told him what I had seen. He said, "This is a true vision, God willing. Go with Bilal and tell him what you saw, and let him call to prayer with it, for he has a more resonant voice than you." So I went with Bilal and told him what I had seen, and he called to prayer with it. Umar bin Al-Khattab heard this while he was in his house. He came out dragging his cloak, saying, "By Him Who sent you with the truth, O Messenger of Allah, I saw the same as he saw." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said, "Praise be to Allah."

title: The Hijra of the Companions to Medina.
details: When the Pledge of Al-Aqabah was completed, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered those who were with him to migrate to Medina. So they left in groups. Among the first to migrate after the second Al-Aqabah was Mus'ab ibn Umayr, then 'Amir ibn Rab'ah, an ally of Banu 'Adi ibn Ka'b, with his wife Layla bint Abi Hathmah ibn Ghanam. Then 'Abdullah ibn Jahsh with his family and his brother 'Abd ibn Jahsh, Abu Ahmad, who was blind. Their dwelling and the dwelling of Abu Salamah were in Quba' among Banu 'Amr ibn 'Awf. When all of Banu Jahsh migrated with their women, Abu Sufyan seized their homes and took possession of them. 'Abdullah ibn Jahsh mentioned this to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, when he learned of it. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to him: "Are you not pleased, O 'Abdullah, that Allah will give you a house in Paradise better than it?" He said: "Yes." He said: "Then it is for you." When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, conquered Mecca, Abu Ahmad spoke to him about their homes. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, delayed him. The people said to Abu Ahmad: "O Abu Ahmad, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, dislikes that you should return concerning something that befell you for the sake of Allah." So he refrained from speaking to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. And Banu Ghanam ibn Duudan were people of Islam who had all migrated to Medina. Then 'Umar ibn Al-Khattab and 'Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah migrated with twenty riders and arrived in Medina. Hisham ibn Al-'As ibn Wa'il had embraced Islam and had agreed with 'Umar ibn Al-Khattab to migrate with him, saying: "You will find me or I will find you at the watering place of Banu Ghifar." His people realized this and prevented him from migrating. Then Abu Jahl and Al-Harith ibn Hisham left until they arrived in Medina while the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was in Mecca. They spoke to 'Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah, who was their brother by their mother and their cousin, and informed him that their mother had vowed not to wash her head or seek shade until she saw him. His heart softened, and he believed them and set out returning with them. They then bound him on the road and brought him to Mecca, in broad daylight, bound. Then they said: "O people of Mecca, do this to your foolish ones as we have done to our foolish one." So they imprisoned him there until Allah, the Exalted, delivered him afterward through the supplication of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in the Qunut of prayer: "O Allah, save Al-Walid ibn Al-Walid, and Salamah ibn Hisham, and 'Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah." When Suhayb ibn Sinan intended to migrate, the disbelievers of Quraysh said to him: "You came to us as a penniless, insignificant person, and your wealth increased among us, and you reached what you reached, and now you want to leave with your wealth and yourself. No, by Allah, that will not happen." Suhayb said to them: "What if I give you all my wealth, will you let me go?" They said: "Yes." He said: "Then I have given it to you." This reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and he said: "Suhayb has profited, Suhayb has profited." Then the emigrants continued to migrate to Medina until the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, migrated.

title: The polytheists' meeting in Dar al-Nadwah and their agreement to kill the Prophet, peace be upon him.
details: When the polytheists saw that the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had prepared and departed, carrying and driving their families, children, and wealth to the Aws and Khazraj in Yathrib, they were overcome by gloom and sorrow, and anxiety and worry besieged them. The chieftains of Mecca gathered in Dar al-Nadwah to make a decisive decision on this matter. Their meeting took place approximately two and a half months after the Pledge of Aqabah. All the representatives of the Quraysh tribes converged for this meeting to discuss a decisive plan that would ensure the swift elimination of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his call. When they arrived at Dar al-Nadwah at the appointed time, Iblis intercepted them in the guise of a venerable old man and stood at the door. They asked, "Who is this old man?" He replied, "An old man from Najd who heard about what you have agreed upon and has come to join you to hear what you say, and perhaps he may offer you his opinion and advice." They said, "Yes, enter." So he entered with them. After the meeting was complete and a lengthy discussion ensued, Abu al-Aswad said, "Let us expel him from among us and banish him from our lands, and we will not care where he goes or where he ends up. We will have rectified our affairs and restored our unity as it was." The Najdi old man said, "No, by God, this is not a good opinion for you. Have you not seen the eloquence of his speech, the sweetness of his tongue, and how he has captivated the hearts of men with what he brings? By God, if you do this, you will not be safe from him settling among some Arab tribe, and then marching with them against you, after they have followed him, until he tramples you in your lands and then does to you whatever he wishes. Devise a different plan for him." Abu al-Bakhtari said, "Let us imprison him in chains and lock him behind a door, and then wait for him to meet the fate of those like him among the poets who came before him – Zuhayr and al-Nabighah – and those who have passed from this death, until he meets the same end." The Najdi old man said, "No, by God, this is not a good opinion for you. By God, if you imprison him, as you say, his cause will emerge from behind the door you have locked him behind to his companions, and they will soon rise up against you, snatch him from your hands, and then increase their numbers against you until they overcome you in your affairs. This is not a good opinion for you, so consider something else." After this, the chief of Mecca's criminals, Abu Jahl ibn Hisham, came forward with a sinful proposal that was agreed upon by all present. Abu Jahl said, "By God, I have an opinion on this that I do not think you have yet considered." They asked, "And what is it, O Abu al-Hakam?" He replied, "I suggest that we take a strong, noble, and respected young man from each tribe. Then we give each of these young men a sharp sword, and they all go to him and strike him with a single blow, killing him. Thus, we will be rid of him. For if they do this, his blood will be dispersed among all the tribes, and the Banu Abd Manaf will not be able to fight all their people. They will then accept blood money from us, and we will pay it to them." The Najdi old man said, "The statement is as the man said. This is the opinion, and there is no other opinion." They unanimously agreed to this sinful proposal.

title: The migration of the Messenger, peace be upon him, and Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, to Medina.
details: Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, narrated that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to the Muslims: "I have been shown the land of your emigration, a land of date palms between two lava fields." These are the two Harrahs. So, those who had emigrated to Medina did so, and most of those who had emigrated to the land of Abyssinia returned to Medina. Abu Bakr prepared to go to Medina, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him: "Take it easy, for I hope I will be given permission." Abu Bakr said: "May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, do you hope for that?" He said: "Yes." So Abu Bakr detained himself to accompany the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he fed two riding beasts he owned with the leaves of the samur tree – which is called khabat – for four months. Ibn Shihab said: Urwah said: Aisha said: One day, while we were sitting in Abu Bakr's house at the height of noon, someone said to Abu Bakr: "Here is the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, veiled, at an hour he does not usually visit us." Abu Bakr said: "May my father and mother be sacrificed for him, by Allah, he has not come at this hour except for something important." She said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, came and asked for permission, and he was granted permission and entered. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Abu Bakr: "Send out those who are with you." Abu Bakr said: "They are only your family, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "I have been given permission to leave." Abu Bakr said: "To accompany you, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah?" The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Yes." Abu Bakr said: "Then take, may my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of Allah, one of these two riding beasts of mine." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "For a price." Aisha said: We prepared them with the best possible preparation, and we made provisions for them in a waterskin. Asma bint Abi Bakr cut a piece from her belt and tied it around the mouth of the waterskin. It was because of this that she was named "Dhat al-Nitaqayn" (She of the Two Belts). She said: Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr joined them in a cave on Mount Thawr, and they hid there for three nights. Abdullah ibn Abi Bakr, a young, intelligent, and quick-witted boy, would spend the night with them, and then leave them before dawn to be with Quraysh in Mecca as if he had spent the night there. He would hear nothing of any plan devised against them without memorizing it, until he would bring them news of it when darkness fell. Amir ibn Fuhayrah, the freed slave of Abu Bakr, would bring them a herd of sheep for grazing, and bring them to rest with them when an hour after Isha had passed. They would spend the night on the milk of their herd and their drink until Amir ibn Fuhayrah would call them at dawn. He did this every night of those three nights. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr hired a man from the tribe of Banu al-Dil, who was from Banu Abd ibn Adi, a guide and an expert navigator – and an expert navigator is one skilled in guidance. He had an alliance with the family of Al-As ibn Wa'il al-Sahmi, and he was on the religion of the disbelievers of Quraysh. So they entrusted him with their riding beasts and agreed to meet him at the cave of Thawr after three nights, with their riding beasts, on the morning of the third day. Amir ibn Fuhayrah and the guide set off with them, and they took the coastal route. Surraqah ibn Ju'shum said: Messengers from the disbelievers of Quraysh came to us, offering a reward for the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr, whoever killed or captured either of them. While I was sitting in a gathering of my people, Banu Mudlij, a man from them came and stood before us while we were sitting, and said: "O Surraqah, I have just seen some dark shapes on the coast. I think it is Muhammad and his companions." Surraqah said: I knew it was them, so I said to him: "They are not them, but you saw so-and-so and so-and-so. They have gone from our sight." I then remained in the gathering for a while, then I got up and went inside and ordered my slave girl to bring out my horse from behind a hill and keep it for me. I took my spear and went out with it from the back of the house, and I struck its tip against the ground, and lowered its upper part, until I reached my horse and mounted it. I urged it on, and it brought me closer, until I was near them. My horse stumbled, and I fell off it. I got up and reached for my quiver, and took out the arrows for divination, and cast lots to see if I would harm them or not. The result I disliked came out. I mounted my horse and disobeyed the arrows, and it brought me closer, until when I heard the recitation of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he did not look back, and Abu Bakr kept looking back, my horse's legs sank into the ground, up to its knees. I fell off it, then I urged it on and it rose, and it could hardly pull its legs out. When it stood upright, there was a cloud of dust rising into the sky like smoke from the tracks of its legs. I cast lots again, and the result I disliked came out. I called out to them offering safety, and they stopped. I mounted my horse and rode until I reached them. When I encountered what I encountered of being held back from them, it occurred to me that the cause of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would prevail. I said to him: "Your people have offered a reward for you, and I informed them of what people intended for them. I offered them provisions and supplies, but they did not take anything from me nor ask me, except that he said: 'Conceal yourselves from us.'" I asked him to write me a letter of security, so he ordered Amir ibn Fuhayrah to write it on a piece of leather. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, departed. Urwah ibn al-Zubayr narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, met al-Zubayr with a group of Muslims who were traders returning from Syria. Al-Zubayr clothed the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and Abu Bakr in white garments. The Muslims in Medina heard of the Messenger of Allah's departure from Mecca, so they would go out every morning to the Harrah and wait for him until the heat of noon drove them back. One day, after waiting for a long time, they returned. When they returned to their homes, a man from the Jews climbed one of their fortresses to look at something. He saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions, dressed in white, shimmering in the heat haze. The Jew could not help but say in a loud voice: "O Arabs, this is your ancestor whom you await!" The Muslims rushed to their weapons and met the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, at the back of the Harrah. He turned them to the right, until he settled them in the territory of Banu Amr ibn Awf. This was on Monday in the month of Rabi al-Awwal. Abu Bakr stood up for the people, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sat in silence. Those who came from the Ansar – who had not seen the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him – began to greet Abu Bakr, until the sun shone on the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. Abu Bakr came and shaded him with his cloak, and then the people recognized the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

title: The construction of the Quba Mosque.
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, stayed in the Banu Amr ibn Awf in Quba for over ten nights, and there he founded the mosque which was founded on piety, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed in it.

title: The construction of the Prophet's Mosque.
details:
The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, mounted his riding beast from Quba and set out, people walking with him until it knelt near the Mosque of the Messenger, peace be upon him, in Medina. On that day, men from among the Muslims were praying there. It was a date palm drying ground belonging to Suhail and Sahl, two orphaned boys under the care of As'ad ibn Zurarah. When his riding beast knelt, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said, "This, God willing, is the place of dwelling." Then the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, called the two boys and negotiated with them for the drying ground to make it a mosque. They said, "No, rather we gift it to you, O Messenger of God." But the Messenger of God refused to accept it as a gift until he bought it from them. Then he built a mosque. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, began to carry bricks with them in its construction, and while carrying bricks, he would say, "This is a burden, not the burden of Khaybar. This is more righteous and purer for our Lord." And he would say, "O God, the reward is the reward of the Hereafter, so have mercy on the Ansar and the Muhajirun."

Anas, may God be pleased with him, said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, arrived in Medina and stayed in the upper part of the city in a tribe called Banu 'Amr ibn 'Awf. The Prophet, peace be upon him, stayed with them for fourteen nights. Then he sent for Banu an-Najjar, and they came, girded with swords, as if I were looking at the Prophet, peace be upon him, on his riding beast, with Abu Bakr behind him, and the notables of Banu an-Najjar around him, until he arrived at the courtyard of Abu Ayyub. He used to like to pray wherever prayer found him, and to pray in sheep pens. He ordered the construction of the mosque, so he sent for a group of Banu an-Najjar and said, "O Banu an-Najjar, name your price for this courtyard of yours." They said, "By God, we will not ask for its price except from God." Anas said: It contained, as I tell you, the graves of the polytheists, ruins, and palm trees. The Prophet, peace be upon him, ordered the graves of the polytheists to be exhumed, then the ruins to be leveled, and the palm trees to be cut down. They lined up the palm trees as the qiblah of the mosque, made its doorposts of stone, and began to carry rocks, chanting, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, was with them, saying, "O God, there is no good except the good of the Hereafter, so forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirun." Abdullah ibn Umar said: The mosque in the time of the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, was built with bricks, its roof was made of palm fronds, and its columns were made of palm wood.

title: The brotherhood between the Emigrants and the Helpers.
details:
Among the consequences of his migration, and that of his Companions, to Medina was the brotherhood established between the Emigrants and the Helpers, may Allah be pleased with them. In the beginning, some of them would inherit from others. It is narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them, regarding the verse: {And for each, We have appointed heirs} he said: "Heirs." And regarding: {And those with whom your right hands have covenanted} he said: "When the Emigrants arrived in Medina, an Emigrant would inherit from an Helper, to the exclusion of his own relatives, due to the brotherhood that the Prophet, peace be upon him, had established between them. When the verse {And for each, We have appointed heirs} was revealed, it abrogated that. Then he said: {And those with whom your right hands have covenanted} meaning: "Except for support, assistance, and sincere advice. Inheritance was then abolished, but one would still make a will for them."

Anas narrated: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, arrived in Medina, the Emigrants came to him and said: "O Messenger of Allah, we have not seen a people more generous than those among whom we have landed, nor more compassionate with little than they are with much. They have spared us hardship and shared their ease with us, to the extent that we fear they will take all the reward." The Prophet, peace be upon him, replied: "Not so, as long as you supplicate to Allah for them and praise them."

Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf, may Allah be pleased with him, said: When we arrived in Medina, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, established brotherhood between me and Sa'd ibn al-Rabi'. Sa'd ibn al-Rabi' said: "I am the wealthiest of the Helpers. I will give you half of my wealth, and look at whichever of my two wives you desire; I will divorce her for you, and when her waiting period is over, you may marry her." Abd al-Rahman said: "I have no need for that. Is there a market where trade occurs?" He said: "The market of Qaynuqa'." Abd al-Rahman went there and brought back some dried yogurt and ghee. He continued to go daily, and before long, Abd al-Rahman returned with a trace of yellow on him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, asked: "Have you married?" He said: "Yes." He asked: "And whom?" He said: "A woman from the Helpers." He asked: "What did you pay as dowry?" He said: "The weight of a date pit of gold – or a date pit of gold." The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him: "Hold a wedding feast, even if it be with a sheep."

title: The expedition of Ubaydah ibn al-Harith ibn al-Muttalib to the valley of Rabigh.
details: The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent Ubaydah ibn al-Harith ibn Abd al-Muttalib on a mission to Batn Rabigh – which is the miqat for the people of Sham, Egypt, Turkey, and those who follow their route – in Sha'ban, eight months after the Hijra. He gave him a white banner, which was carried by Misṭaḥ ibn Uthathah ibn al-Muttalib ibn Abd Manaf. They were sixty emigrants, with no Ansar among them. They encountered Abu Sufyan ibn Harb, who was with two hundred men at Batn Rabigh, ten miles from al-Juhfah. There was archery between them, but they did not draw their swords, nor did they line up for battle. It was merely a skirmish. Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas was among them, and he was the first to shoot an arrow in the cause of Allah. Then, both parties returned to their respective encampments.

title: The expedition of Hamza to the Sea of Reeds.
details: The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent a detachment to the coast of the sea, appointing Hamza ibn Abd al-Muttalib as its commander. He sent him with thirty riders from the Emigrants. Hamza's banner was the first banner that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, tied, and it was white. Its bearer was Abu Murthad Kannaz ibn Husayn al-Ghanawi, may Allah be pleased with him. The objective of this detachment was to intercept a caravan of Quraysh coming from Sham, which included Abu Jahl ibn Hisham with three hundred men. They reached the coast of the sea near Al-`Is - a place near Medina on the coast of the sea - and they met and lined up for battle. Majdi ibn Amr al-Juhani - who was an ally to both sides - walked between them until he separated them, so they did not fight. Hamza's detachment, may Allah be pleased with him, was at the same time as Ubaydah ibn al-Harith's detachment, may Allah be pleased with him, to Rabigh.

title: The expedition of Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, to al-Kharrar.
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, with twenty of the Emigrants, nine months after the Hijra. It is also said that it was eight. They were sent to Al-Kharrar. He tied a white banner for him, which was carried by Al-Miqdad ibn Amr, may Allah be pleased with him. Al-Kharrar is a valley from which one reaches Al-Juhfah. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, instructed him not to go beyond it, so that they might intercept a caravan of Quraysh passing by. They set out on foot, hiding during the day and traveling at night, until they reached the mentioned location at dawn on the fifth day. They found that the caravan had already passed the day before. So they turned back to Medina without engaging in any battle.

title: The Battle of al-Abwa' (Waddan) and the truce with Banu Damrah.
details: The first expedition the Prophet, peace be upon him, undertook was to Al-Abwa, then to Buwat, then to Al-Ushairah. Al-Ushairah is a village in the region of Al-Fur', located twenty-three miles from Al-Juhfah in the direction of Medina. It is said to have been named thus due to the plague that was there. This was the expedition of Waddan, with a stressed "dal". Ishaq said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, went out on an expedition himself until he reached Waddan, which is Al-Abwa. He departed from Medina twelve months after his arrival in Medina, intending to confront Quraysh. He made a treaty with Banu Damrah bin Bakr bin Abd Manat, from Kinanah. Their chief, Makhshi bin Amr al-Damri, made a treaty with him, and he returned without fighting. The Prophet, peace be upon him, had appointed Sa'd bin Ubadah as his deputy in Medina. It is also said that when the Prophet, peace be upon him, reached Al-Abwa, he sent Ubaidah bin Al-Harith with sixty men. They encountered a group from Quraysh, and they exchanged arrows. Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas shot an arrow, and he was the first to shoot an arrow in the cause of Allah.

title: The First Battle of Badr (Wadi Safwan).
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, embarked on the first expedition to Badr until he reached the valley of Safwan. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, set out thirteen months after his Hijra, seeking Kurz ibn Jabir al-Fihri. Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, carried his banner, which was white. He appointed Zayd ibn Harithah as his deputy in Medina. Kurz had raided the herds of Medina – the camels and livestock that grazed in the morning – and had driven them away. He was grazing them in the protected pasture. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, pursued him until he reached a valley called Safwan, in the vicinity of Badr. However, Kurz escaped him and he did not catch him, so he returned to Medina.

title: The Battle of Bu'at, near Yanbu.
details: Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: We were on an expedition with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) to the valley of Buwat, and he was seeking Majdi bin Amr al-Juhani. We were taking turns riding the camel, five, six, or seven of us. It was the turn of an Ansari man to ride his camel. He dismounted it and rode it, then urged it on, but it was slow to respond. He said to it: "Get up, may Allah curse you." The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Who is it that has cursed his camel?" He replied: "I did, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Get off it, and do not accompany us while you are cursed. Do not invoke curses upon yourselves, nor upon your children, nor upon your property, lest you happen to ask Allah for something at a time when He grants requests, and He answers you." Buwat is a mountain in the mountains of Juhaynah, near Yanbu.

title: The Battle of Al-Ushairah (Al-Usayrah).
details: It was said to Zayd ibn Arqam: "How many expeditions did the Prophet, peace be upon him, participate in?" He said: "Nineteen." It was said: "How many did you participate in with him?" He said: "Seventeen." It was said: "Which one was the first?" He said: "Al-Usayrah, or Al-Ushayr." The expedition of Al-Ushayr occurred before the Battle of Badr. The Prophet, peace be upon him, took the path of Bani Dinar, then the plain of Al-Khabar, and camped under a tree in Batḥā' Ibn Azhar called Dhat Al-Saq. He prayed there... Food was prepared for him there, and he ate from it, and the people ate with him... Water was brought for him from a well called Al-Mushtarib. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, departed, leaving the people to his left, and took a path called Shu'bat Abdullah... Then he descended to the left until he reached Yallil, where he camped at the confluence of Yallil and the confluence of Al-Dab'ah. He drank from a well in Al-Dab'ah, then took the path of Farsh, the path of Malal, until he reached the road at Suhayrat, at Sukhayrat Al-Yamam. Then the road straightened for him until he reached Al-Ushayr from the valley of Yanbu'. He stayed there during Jumada al-Ula and some nights of Jumada al-Akhirah. There, he made a truce with Bani Mudlij and their allies from Bani Damrah, and then returned to Medina without encountering any hardship.

title: The expedition of Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, to Rabigh.
details: Ibn Asakir narrated from Al-Zuhri, who said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent a detachment including Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, to a region of the Hijaz called Rabegh. The polytheists attacked the Muslims, and on that day, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him, came to them with his arrows. He was the first to shoot an arrow in the cause of Allah, and this was the first battle in Islam."

title: The expedition of Abdullah ibn Jahsh al-Asadi to Nakhla.
details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, sent his messenger Abdullah ibn Jahsh al-Asadi to Nakhlah in Rajab, seventeen months after the Hijra, with twelve men from the Muhajirun, each pair sharing a camel. They reached the valley of Nakhlah to scout a caravan of Quraysh. In this expedition, Abdullah ibn Jahsh was named the Commander of the Faithful. The Messenger of God had written him a letter and ordered him not to look at it until he had traveled for two days, then to look at it. When he opened the letter, he found: "When you look at this letter of mine, proceed until you descend to Nakhlah, between Mecca and Ta'if, and scout Quraysh there, and learn their news for us." He said, "We hear and obey," and informed his companions of this, stating that he did not compel them. Whoever desired martyrdom should proceed, and whoever disliked death should return. As for me, I am proceeding. So they all proceeded. While on the way, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas and Utbah ibn Ghazwan lost a camel they were sharing, so they fell behind to search for it. Abdullah ibn Jahsh proceeded until he reached Nakhlah. A caravan of Quraysh passed by him carrying raisins, dried meat, and merchandise, which included Amr ibn al-Hadrami, Uthman and Nawfal ibn Abdullah ibn al-Mughirah, and al-Hakam ibn Kaysan, a freed slave of Banu al-Mughirah. The Muslims consulted among themselves and said, "We are on the last day of the sacred month of Rajab. If we fight them, we will violate the sacred month. If we leave them tonight, they will enter the sanctuary." Then they agreed to confront them. One of them threw a spear at Amr ibn al-Hadrami and killed him, and they captured Uthman and al-Hakam, while Nawfal escaped. Then they returned with the caravan and the two captives, having set aside the fifth, which was the first fifth in Islam, and the first killing in Islam, and the first two captives in Islam. The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, disapproved of what they had done, and Quraysh's hostility and denial intensified. They claimed to have found a pretext, saying: Muhammad has made the sacred month permissible. This weighed heavily on the Muslims until God Almighty revealed: {They ask you about the sacred month, about fighting in it. Say, "Fighting in it is great [sin], but barring [people] from the way of God and disbelief in Him and [preventing access to] al-Masjid al-Haram and the expulsion of its people from it are greater [evil] with God. And affliction is greater than killing.} [Al-Baqarah: 217].

title: The Change of the Qibla to the Kaaba.
details: From Al-Bara' ibn 'Azib, may Allah be pleased with them both, who said: "When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, arrived in Medina, he prayed towards Jerusalem for sixteen or seventeen months. He loved to be directed towards the Kaaba, so Allah the Almighty revealed: {We have certainly seen the turning of your face, [O Muhammad], toward the heaven, and We will surely turn you to a qiblah with which you shall be well-pleased} [Al-Baqarah: 144]. So he was directed towards the Kaaba. A man prayed the 'Asr prayer with him, then he went out and passed by some of the Ansar. He said: I bear witness that I prayed with the Prophet, peace be upon him, and that he was directed towards the Kaaba. So they turned while they were bowing in the 'Asr prayer."

title: The obligation of fasting the month of Ramadan was revealed.
details: In this year, the fasting of the month of Ramadan was ordained. It has also been said that the obligation of fasting the month of Ramadan was before the Battle of Badr.

title: The obligation of Zakat al-Fitr was ordained.
details: Allah, the Exalted, has ordained the Zakat al-Fitr, which is obligatory upon every Muslim, whether free or slave, male or female, young or old, who is able to pay it. The wisdom behind it is to purify the fasting person from any idle talk or obscenity they may have committed during fasting, and to provide assistance to the poor, bringing them joy on the day of Eid.

title: The Expedition of 'Umayr ibn 'Adi, may Allah be pleased with him, to kill 'Asma bint Marwan.
details: Asma bint Marwan, from Banu Umayyah ibn Zayd, wife of Yazid ibn Zayd ibn Hisn al-Khatmi, used to criticize Islam, harm the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and incite against him. She would throw menstrual cloths in the mosque of Banu Khatmah. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, declared her blood forfeit. Umayr ibn Adi vowed that if the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned to Medina from Badr, he would kill her, and he did so, may Allah be pleased with him. When Umayr returned, he found her sons with a group burying her. They said, "O Umayr, did you kill her?" He replied, "Yes, so plot against me all together, then give me no respite. By Him in whose hand is my soul, if all of you said what she said, I would strike you with this sword of mine until I die or I kill you." On that day, Islam appeared among Banu Khatmah, and whoever among them had embraced Islam used to conceal it. The first among Banu Khatmah to embrace Islam was Umayr ibn Adi, who is also called Al-Qari.

title: The Battle of Badr (the Great) and the Victory of the Muslims.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, dispatched a group of Muslims to intercept the Quraysh caravan coming from Syria, which was led by Abu Sufyan. Abu Sufyan later learned of the Muslims' departure and sent a message to Quraysh calling for their aid to rescue their trade. He also changed his route to save the caravan. Then, the Muslims and the polytheists met at Badr, a place between Mecca and Medina, and closer to Medina than Mecca. The number of polytheists was nearly a thousand, while the number of Muslims was over three hundred. The battle began with the famous duel, then the fighting started and was intense. Prominent leaders of Quraysh, such as Abu Jahl and Umayyah ibn Khalaf, and others were killed, with their total dead reaching seventy men and the same number taken captive. Fourteen Muslims were killed, and some say sixteen. Thus, a great victory was achieved by the Muslims. God Almighty aided them and sent angels to fight alongside them. Regarding the captives, Umar suggested killing them, while Abu Bakr suggested ransoming them. The Prophet, peace be upon him, accepted Abu Bakr's opinion, but revelation descended in agreement with Umar's view. As for the spoils of war, the chapter of Al-Anfal was revealed concerning them.

title: The passing of Ruqayyah, may Allah be pleased with her.
details: She is Ruqayyah, daughter of the Master of Mankind, peace be upon him. She was the wife of Uthman ibn Affan, may Allah be pleased with them both. Ruqayyah was initially married to Utbah ibn Abi Lahab. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, was sent [with his message], Abu Lahab ordered his son to divorce her. Uthman then married her and migrated with her to Abyssinia. When the Messenger of Allah called upon the people to go out to intercept the caravan of Abu Sufyan, he ordered Uthman to remain with Ruqayyah to nurse her and care for her. This was the reason for his absence. The Prophet, peace be upon him, granted him a share [of the spoils] as he did for those who were present at Badr. Then Ruqayyah did not remain long in her illness before she passed away, may Allah be pleased with her.

title: The Expedition of Salim ibn Umayr, may Allah be pleased with him, to Abu Afak the Jew.
details: The expedition of Salim bin Umayr, may Allah be pleased with him, to Abu Afak the Jew took place in Shawwal, at the beginning of the twentieth month after the Hijra of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Abu Afak was from the Banu Amr bin Awf, an old man who had reached the age of one hundred and twenty years. He was a Jew, greatly disbelieving, and a harsh critic of the Muslims. His heart was filled with hatred and envy towards the Muslims as he saw the Aws and Khazraj rallying to support the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. His malice towards Islam and its people intensified after he saw the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, growing stronger and more established in Medina and its surroundings after the Battle of Badr. He could not bear it, so he began to recite poetry, denouncing the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, inciting enmity towards him, and ridiculing the opinion of the Ansar for following and supporting the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Salim bin Umayr, who was one of the "weepers" – meaning during the Battle of Tabuk – and a participant in the Battle of Badr, said: "I vow to kill Abu Afak or die trying." He waited, seeking an opportunity, until one summer night when Abu Afak slept in the courtyard. Salim bin Umayr heard of this, approached him, placed his sword on his abdomen, and then leaned on it until it sank into his body. The enemy of Allah cried out, and some of his followers came to him, brought him into his house, and buried him. Abu Afak was among those whose hypocrisy became evident when the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, killed Al-Harith bin Suwayd bin Al-Samit. Salim participated in the Battle of Badr, Uhud, the Trench, and all the other battles with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He passed away during the caliphate of Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan, may Allah be pleased with them both.

title: The Battle of Banu Qaynuqa.
details: Most historians of battles and biographies mentioned that it occurred after Badr, and Ibn Hajar favored this view. It took place on Saturday, the middle of Shawwal. The report of the expulsion of Banu Qaynuqa' is established in the two Sahih collections. It is narrated from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that he said: "An-Nadir and Qurayzah fought, so he expelled Banu An-Nadir and let Qurayzah and those with them remain, until Qurayzah fought. Then he killed their men and divided their women, children, and property among the Muslims, except for some of them who joined the Prophet, peace be upon him, and he granted them safety and they embraced Islam. And he expelled all the Jews of Medina: Banu Qaynuqa' – who were the kin of Abdullah ibn Salam – and the Jews of Banu Harithah, and all the Jews of Medina."

title: The Expedition of As-Sawiq, or the Expedition of Banu Sulaym (Qarqarat al-Kadr).
details: After the defeat of the polytheists at Badr, Abu Sufyan vowed that no water from ritual impurity would touch his head until he invaded Muhammad, peace be upon him, and his companions and took revenge on the Muslims. So he set out with two hundred riders from Quraysh, to fulfill his oath. He reached the outskirts of Medina at night and sought refuge with Banu Nadir. He went to Huyayy ibn Akhtab and knocked on his door, but Huyayy refused to open it for him, fearing him. So Abu Sufyan turned away from him to Salam ibn Mishkam, who was the chief of Banu Nadir at that time and the keeper of their treasure. Abu Sufyan asked for permission to enter, and he was granted it. Salam hosted him, gave him wine to drink, and informed him of the news of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Then Abu Sufyan left in the latter part of that night and went to his companions. He sent some men from Quraysh, who went to an area of Medina called Al-Arid – a valley in Medina. They set fire to the fruit-bearing trees and date palms of the Muslims. They found a man from the Ansar and his ally in their fields and killed them, then they turned back. When this news reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he set out in pursuit of them with two hundred of the Emigrants and Helpers. He appointed Abu Lubaba Bashir ibn Abd al-Mundhir, may Allah be pleased with him, as governor of Medina. Abu Sufyan and his companions began to throw down sacks of saweeq – roasted wheat or barley, then ground, and used as provisions, mixed with water, ghee, or honey – which was the majority of their provisions, to lighten their load for escape. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, reached Qaraqarah al-Kadr – Qaraqarah: level ground. Al-Kadr: a water source belonging to Banu Sulaym, and the origin of Kadr is a bird with a dusky color, after which the place or water was named. Then he turned back towards Medina, as Abu Sufyan and his companions had escaped him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was away for five days. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned with them, the Muslims said, "O Messenger of Allah, do you hope that this will be a raid for us?" He said, "Yes." This raid is also called the "Raid of Saweeq" because the most of what the people threw away from their provisions was saweeq, so the Muslims returned with a lot of saweeq. This occurred in Shawwal in the second year of the Hijra.

title: The Killing of Ka'b ibn al-Ashraf.
details: Ka'b ibn al-Ashraf was a man from the tribe of Tayy, and his mother was from the Banu Nadir, a Jewish tribe. He was a poet who used to lampoon the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his companions, inciting hatred against them and causing them harm. When the Battle of Badr occurred, he was disheartened and humiliated, saying, "The belly of the earth is better than its surface today." He then went to Mecca, wept for the slain Quraysh, and incited them with poetry. Jabir ibn Abdullah narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said, "Who will deal with Ka'b ibn al-Ashraf? For he has indeed harmed Allah and His Messenger." Muhammad ibn Maslamah said, "O Messenger of Allah, would you like me to kill him?" He replied, "Yes." He said, "Grant me permission to speak." The Prophet said, "Speak." So, Muhammad ibn Maslamah went to Ka'b and said to him, mentioning what transpired between them, "This man has asked for charity and has burdened us." When Ka'b heard this, he said, "And by Allah, you will soon be weary of him." Muhammad replied, "We have followed him now, and we dislike leaving him until we see what becomes of his affair. He also said, "And I wanted you to lend me some money." Ka'b asked, "What will you give me as collateral?" Muhammad replied, "What do you want?" Ka'b said, "You will give us your women as collateral." Muhammad replied, "You are the most handsome of the Arabs; shall we give you our women as collateral!?" Ka'b then said, "You will give me your children as collateral." Muhammad replied, "One of our children is insulted, and it is said, 'He was ransomed for two measures of dates.' But we will give you our weapons as collateral." Ka'b said, "Then fine." He promised to bring him Al-Harith, Abu 'Abs ibn Jabr, and 'Abbad ibn Bishr. Muhammad said, "So they came and called him at night, and he came down to them." Sufyan said, "Others than 'Amr said: His wife said to him, 'I hear a sound like the sound of blood.' He said, 'It is only Muhammad ibn Maslamah, his companion, and Abu Na'ilah. Indeed, the generous man, if invited to a stab in the night, would respond.' Muhammad said, 'When he comes, I will reach for his head, and when I have a firm grip on him, then it is yours.' He said, 'When he came down, he was wearing perfume. They said, "We detect the scent of perfume on you." He said, "Yes, so-and-so is under me; she is the most fragrant of the Arab women." He said, "Will you permit me to smell it?" He said, "Yes, smell it." So he took it and smelled it, then said, "Will you permit me to return?" He said, "He gained a firm grip on his head, then said, 'It is yours.'" He said, "So they killed him." (...Then they came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and informed him.)

title: The raid of Ghatafan on Najd (the Raid of Dhu Amr).
details: This was the Ghazwah of Dhu Amarr, in the region of Najd. The reason for it was that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, received news that a group from Banu Tha'labah ibn Sa'id ibn Dhubyan ibn Baghidh ibn Ra'ith ibn Ghatafan, and Banu Muharib ibn Khasafah ibn Qays, at Dhu Amarr, had gathered, intending to raid the frontiers of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. A man from them, called Du'thur ibn Al-Harith ibn Muharib, had united them. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, summoned the Muslims and set out with four hundred and fifty men, accompanied by several horses. He appointed Uthman ibn Affan as his deputy in Medina. They encountered a man from them at Dhu al-Qassah, called Jabbar from Banu Tha'labah. The Muslims asked him, "Where are you going?" He replied, "I am going to Yathrib to scout for myself and look around." He was brought to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and informed him of their news. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said, "They will not meet you. If they hear of your march, they will flee to the mountain tops. I am going with you." So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, invited Jabbar to Islam, and he embraced Islam. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, attached him to Bilal, and Jabbar led them along a path, bringing them down to them. The people heard of the march of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and fled to the mountain tops. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, reached a water source called Dhu Amarr and camped there. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions were struck by heavy rain, and the clothes of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions became wet. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, descended under a tree and spread his clothes to dry, and lay down, while the polytheists could see him. The Muslims were occupied with their affairs. The polytheists sent a brave man from them, called Du'thur ibn Al-Harith, who was their chief and bravest. He was girded with a sword. Du'thur rushed forward, drawing his sword, until he stood over the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, with his sword drawn, and said, "O Muhammad, who will protect you from me today?" The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, replied, "Allah." Gabriel pushed him in the chest, and the sword fell from his hand. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, took it and said to him, "Who will protect you from me?!" He replied, "No one." And I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. By Allah, I will never gather a force against you again. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gave him his sword. Then he came to his people, and they asked him, "What happened to you? Woe to you!" He said, "I saw a tall man who pushed me in the chest, and I fell on my back. I knew he was an angel, and I testified that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah. By Allah, I will never gather a force against him again." And he began to call his people to Islam. And Allah, the Almighty, revealed: "O you who have believed, remember the favor of Allah upon you when a people intended to extend their hands [in aggression] against you, but He restrained their hands from you." [Al-Ma'idah, 11]. And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, returned to Medina without encountering any harm. His absence was fifteen nights. It was also said that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stayed in Najd for the entire month of Safar.

title: The Battle of Bu'ran between Al-Fur' and Medina.
details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, went on an expedition intending to confront Quraysh, and he appointed Abdullah ibn Umm Maktum, may God be pleased with him, as his deputy in Medina. He proceeded until he reached Buhran, in the vicinity of al-Fur'. The reason for this expedition was that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, learned that a large gathering of Banu Sulaym ibn Mansur was present there. So he set out with three hundred of his companions, and he did not reveal the purpose of his journey. When he was one night's journey from Buhran, he encountered a man from Banu Sulaym, who informed them that the people had dispersed. He detained the man with another companion and proceeded until he arrived at Buhran, finding no one there. He stayed for a few days, then returned without encountering any hostility, and released the man. Then he turned back, returning to Medina.

title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah.
details: After their defeat in the Battle of Badr, the polytheists of Mecca began searching for another route for their trade to Syria. Some of them suggested the route of Najd in Iraq, and they indeed took it. Merchants set out from them, including Abu Sufyan ibn Harb, Safwan ibn Umayyah, and Huwaytib ibn Abd al-Uzza, carrying silver and many goods valued at one hundred thousand dirhams. This news reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, through Sulait ibn al-Nu'man, may Allah be pleased with him. So, he sent Zaid ibn Harithah with one hundred riders to intercept the caravan. Zaid encountered the caravan at a watering place called al-Qardah, which is one of the watering places of Najd.
