Its men fled in terror, and the Muslims seized the caravan and its contents. They captured its guide, Furat ibn Hayyan, who embraced Islam at the hands of the Prophet, peace be upon him. They returned to Medina, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, distributed one-fifth of the spoils and divided the remainder among the members of the expedition.

title: The Battle of Uhud and the Reason for the Muslims' Defeat.
details:
The reason for this was that when the polytheists suffered casualties among their nobles at the Battle of Badr, and the caravan with its trade goods, which was with Abu Sufyan, escaped, upon their return to Mecca, the sons of those who were killed and the leaders of those who remained said to Abu Sufyan: "Amass these funds for the war against Muhammad." So they spent them for that purpose, gathered armies and allied tribes, and marched with nearly three thousand men, until they encamped near Uhud, facing Medina.

On Friday, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prayed. After finishing, he prayed over a man from Banu Najjar, named Malik ibn Amr. He then consulted the people, asking whether they should march out to meet the enemy or remain in Medina. Abdullah ibn Ubayy suggested staying in Medina. He argued that if they stayed, they would be in a terrible confinement, and if the enemy entered, the men would fight them face-to-face, while the women and children would pelt them with stones from above. If the enemy retreated, they would return in defeat. Other Companions, who had not witnessed Badr, suggested marching out to meet them. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went inside, donned his armor, and marched out to meet them.

He set out with a thousand of his Companions. When they reached a place called Ash-Shawtt, Abdullah ibn Ubayy turned back with a third of the army, angered because his opinion had not been heeded. He and his followers said: "If we knew there would be fighting today, we would have followed you, but we do not see you fighting today." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, continued his march until he reached the valley of Uhud, at the entrance of the valley. He positioned his back and his camp towards Uhud and prepared for battle with seven hundred of his Companions. He appointed Abdullah ibn Jubayr, brother of Banu Amr ibn Awf, as the commander of the archers, who numbered fifty men that day. He instructed them: "Repel the cavalry from us with arrows, so they do not come at us from behind. Whether we gain victory or suffer defeat, remain in your position, so that we are not attacked from your side." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, wore two coats of mail and gave the banner to Mus'ab ibn Umayr, brother of Banu Abd ad-Dar. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, permitted some of the young boys to participate that day and deferred others.

Quraysh mobilized, numbering three thousand men, with two hundred horses prepared for battle. They appointed Khalid ibn al-Walid to command the right flank of the cavalry and Ikrimah ibn Abi Jahl to command the left flank. The banner was given to Banu Abd ad-Dar.

Then, what happened between the two factions occurred. Initial signs of victory began to appear for the Muslims. When the Muslims saw the polytheists retreating, the archers neglected the Prophet's command to them and descended to collect spoils. Khalid ibn al-Walid seized the opportunity, circled behind them, and engaged them in battle, which led to a reversal of fortunes. The battle concluded with the martyrdom of seventy Muslims, including Hamzah ibn Abd al-Muttalib, Mus'ab ibn Umayr, Abdullah ibn Haram, the father of Jabir, and Abdullah ibn Jubayr, the commander of the archers.

title: The martyrdom of Hamza, may Allah be pleased with him, in the Battle of Uhud.
details: 'Ubayd Allah ibn 'Adi ibn al-Khiyar narrated that he asked Wahshi, the killer of Hamza, "Will you not tell us about the killing of Hamza?" He replied, "Yes. Hamza killed Tu'aymah ibn 'Adi ibn al-Khiyar at Badr. My master, Jubayr ibn Mut'im, said to me, 'If you kill Hamza for my uncle, you are free.' So, when the people went out for the battle of 'Aynayn, and 'Aynayn is a mountain opposite Uhud, with a valley between them, I went out with the people to fight. When they lined up for battle, Sibā' came out and said, 'Is there any duelist?' Hamza ibn 'Abd al-Muttalib came out to him and said, 'O Sibā', O son of Umm Anmar, the cutter of the clitorises, do you defy Allah and His Messenger (peace be upon him)?' Then he attacked him, and he was like yesterday's gone. I lay in wait for Hamza behind a rock. When he came near me, I threw my spear at him, and it lodged in his chest until it came out from between his legs. That was the last I saw of him. When the people returned, I returned with them. I stayed in Mecca until Islam became widespread. Then I went to Ta'if. They sent a messenger to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and I was told, 'He does not harm messengers.' So I went out with them until I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). When he saw me, he said, 'Are you Wahshi?' I said, 'Yes.' He said, 'Did you kill Hamza?' I said, 'What reached you of the matter has happened.' He said, 'Can you hide your face from me?' So I left. When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed away, Musaylimah the Liar emerged. I said, 'I will go out to Musaylimah, perhaps I will kill him and make it equivalent for Hamza.' So I went out with the people, and what happened, happened. I saw a man standing in a breach of a wall, like a tawny camel with disheveled hair. I threw my spear at him, and it lodged between his chest and his navel until it came out from between his shoulders. Then a man from the Ansar rushed at him and struck him on the head with his sword."

title: The Battle of Hamra al-Asad.
details:
Ibn Kathir said in his Tafsir of the verse: "{Those who responded to Allah and the Messenger, even after they had been wounded}" This was on the day of Hamra' al-Asad. When the polytheists inflicted what they inflicted upon the Muslims – meaning on the day of Uhud – they turned back towards their lands. As they continued on their journey, they regretted not having finished off the people of Medina and made it the decisive blow. When this reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he called upon the Muslims to go after them to instill fear in them and show them that they possessed strength and resilience. He did not permit anyone except those who had been present at the battle of Uhud, except for Jabir ibn Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him. The Muslims responded, despite their wounds and exhaustion, in obedience to Allah the Almighty and His Messenger, peace be upon him.

It was narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that she said regarding the verse: "{Those who responded to Allah and the Messenger, even after they had been wounded – for those among them who did good and feared Allah will have a great reward.}" She said to Urwah: "O son of my sister, your fathers were among them: Al-Zubayr and Abu Bakr. When what happened to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, happened on the day of Uhud, and the polytheists departed from him, he feared they might return. He said: 'Who will go after them?' So seventy men volunteered from them. She said: 'Abu Bakr and Al-Zubayr were among them.'"

Ibn Kathir said after mentioning this Hadith: "(This narration is very strange, for it is well-known among the scholars of Maghazi that those who went out with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to Hamra' al-Asad were all who had witnessed Uhud, and they were seven hundred. Seventy of them were killed, and the rest remained)."

The apparent meaning is that there is no contradiction between the words of Aisha and the scholars of Maghazi, because the meaning of her statement: "So seventy men volunteered for it" is that they preceded others, and then the rest joined them. Hamra' al-Asad is located eight miles from Medina.

title: The expedition of Abdullah ibn Abi Sarh, may Allah be pleased with him, to Qatan.
details: The expedition of Abu Salamah Abdullah bin Abdul-Asad, who was the cousin of the Prophet, peace be upon him, through his paternal aunt Barrah bint Abdul-Muttalib, and his foster brother, as they were both nursed by Thuwibah. Qatan is a mountain, and it is also said to be a water source belonging to Banu Asad. The reason for this expedition was that a man from Tayy, named Al-Walid bin Zuhayr bin Tarif, came to Medina to visit his niece, Zaynab, who was married to Tulayb bin Umayr bin Wahb. He was informed that Tulayhah and Salamah, the sons of Khuwaylid, had gathered their people and those who obeyed them to wage war against the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Qays bin Al-Harith advised them against it, but they disobeyed. When this reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he summoned Abu Salamah, may Allah be pleased with him, and said, "Go forth on this expedition, for I have appointed you in command of it." He tied a banner for him and said, "Travel until you reach the land of Banu Asad bin Khuzaymah, and raid them before their forces can gather against you." He also advised him to fear Allah, the Almighty, and to treat the Muslims with him well. So, one hundred and fifty men went with him on this expedition, and the man from Tayy accompanied them as a guide. He traveled swiftly, diverting them from the main road, and journeyed day and night. They outpaced any news and arrived at Dhi Qatan, a water source of Banu Asad, where their forces were gathered. They raided their livestock and captured three shepherds, while the rest escaped. They went to their people and informed them of the news, warning them about Abu Salamah's forces and exaggerating their numbers. Consequently, the gathered forces dispersed in all directions. Abu Salamah arrived at the water source to find the gathering had dispersed. He made camp and divided his companions into three groups to pursue the camels and sheep. One group remained with him, while the other two raided in different directions. He instructed them not to go too far in their pursuit and to return to him if they were safe, and not to separate. He appointed a leader from among them for each group. They all returned to him safely, having acquired camels and sheep, and without encountering anyone. Abu Salamah then headed back to Medina with all the spoils, accompanied by the man from Tayy. After they had traveled for a night, Abu Salamah divided the spoils, setting aside the special share for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, which was a slave. He also set aside the fifth (khums) and gave the guide from Tayy his satisfaction from the spoils. Then he divided the remainder among his companions, and each person received seven camels. He arrived in Medina with all of this without facing any opposition.

title: The expedition of Abdullah ibn Unays al-Juhani to Sufyan ibn Khalid in Batn Urnah.
details: Abdullah bin Unais, may Allah be pleased with him, departed from Medina on Monday, five nights into Muharram, thirty-five months after the Hijra of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. It reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, that Sufyan bin Khalid bin Nabih al-Hudhali, then al-Lahyani – who resided in Urnah and its vicinity with some of his people and others – intended to gather forces against the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and that many people from various backgrounds had joined him. Abdullah bin Unais, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, summoned me and said: "It has reached me that Sufyan bin Khalid bin Nabih is gathering people against me to attack me, and he is in Nakhla or Urnah. Go to him and kill him." I said: O Messenger of Allah, describe him to me so I can recognize him. He said: "The sign between you and him is that when you see him, you will be awestruck and fearful of him, and you will feel a shiver, and you will remember Satan." Abdullah said: I was not afraid of men, so I said: O Messenger of Allah, I have never been afraid of anything. He said: "Yes; that is the sign between you and him: you will feel a shiver when you see him." He said: I asked permission from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to speak. He said: "Say what you wish." And he said: "Claim kinship with Khuzā'ah." So I took my sword and added nothing to it, and I went out claiming kinship with Khuzā'ah. When I reached the valley of Urnah, I met him walking, with a group of Abyssinians behind him. When I saw him, I was awestruck by him and recognized him by the description the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had given me. I said: Allah and His Messenger have spoken the truth. The time for Asr prayer had arrived when I saw him, so I prayed while walking, gesturing with my head. When I approached him, he said: "Who is the man?" I said: "A man from Khuzā'ah. I heard about your gathering against Muhammad, so I came to be with you in it." He said: "Yes; I am indeed among those gathered against him." So I walked with him and talked to him. He found my conversation pleasant, and I recited poetry to him, saying: "How strange is what Muhammad has introduced of this new religion! He has abandoned the ways of our fathers and deemed their wisdom foolish." He said: "I have not met anyone like me, nor anyone who fights as well as I do." He was leaning on a staff, striking the ground with it, until he reached his tent, and his companions dispersed to nearby dwellings, while they surrounded him. He said: "Come here, O brother of Khuzā'ah." I approached him. He said: "Sit down." I sat with him until the people calmed down and slept. I took advantage of the opportunity. In most narrations, it is said that I walked with him until, when I had the opportunity, I struck him with my sword and killed him, and took his head. Then I turned and ascended a mountain, and entered a cave. The pursuit of horses and men came from all directions, while I was hidden in the cave. A man approached with his water skin and sandals in his hand. I was afraid. He put down his water skin and sandals and sat down to urinate near the mouth of the cave. Then he said to his companions: "There is no one in the cave." So they turned back. I went out to the water skin, drank what was in it, and took the two sandals and put them on. I traveled by night and hid by day until I came to Medina. I found the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, in the mosque. When he saw me, he said: "May your face be successful." I said: "And may your face be successful, O Messenger of Allah." I placed the head before him and told him my story. He gave me a staff and said: "Use this to lean on in Paradise; for those who lean on staffs in Paradise are few." The staff remained with Abdullah bin Unais until his death approached. He instructed his family to wrap the staff in his shroud. They did so. Ibn 'Uqbah said: "They claim that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, informed them of Abdullah bin Unais killing Sufyan bin Khalid before Abdullah bin Unais, may Allah Almighty be pleased with him, arrived."

title: The Expedition of the Day of Ar-Raj'i.
details:
Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent out a detachment of ten men as scouts, and appointed Asim bin Thabit Al-Ansari, the grandfather of Asim bin Umar bin Al-Khattab, as their commander. They set out until they reached Al-Hada, which is between Usfan and Mecca. They were discovered by a tribe of Hudhayl called Banu Lihyan. Nearly two hundred archers from their tribe mobilized and tracked their footsteps until they found traces of their meal, dates they had provisioned from Medina. They said, "These are dates from Yathrib." They continued to track their footsteps. When Asim and his companions saw them, they took refuge in a mound of sand, and the enemy surrounded them. They called out to them, "Come down and surrender yourselves, and you will have our covenant and pledge, and we will not kill any of you." Asim bin Thabit, the commander of the detachment, said, "As for me, by Allah, I will not descend under the protection of a disbeliever today. O Allah, inform Your Prophet about us." So they shot arrows at them, and killed Asim and seven of his companions. Three men then descended to them under the covenant and pledge: Khubayb Al-Ansari, Ibn Dathinah, and another man. When they had control over them, they loosened the strings of their bows and bound them. The third man said, "This is the first act of treachery. By Allah, I will not accompany you. I have an example in these slain men," referring to the killed companions. They dragged him and tried to persuade him to accompany them, but he refused, so they killed him. They then took Khubayb and Ibn Dathinah and sold them in Mecca after the Battle of Badr. Khubayb was bought by the sons of Al-Harith bin Amir bin Nawfal bin Abd Manaf. Khubayb had killed Al-Harith bin Amir on the day of Badr. Khubayb remained a captive with them. Ubayd Allah bin Iyad informed me that the daughter of Al-Harith told him that when they gathered, she lent Khubayb a razor to shave with. She said that she found him sitting on his thigh with the razor in his hand, holding her son. She was frightened, a fear that Khubayb recognized in her face. He said, "Are you afraid that I will kill him? I would never do that. By Allah, I have never seen a better captive than Khubayb. By Allah, I once found him eating a bunch of grapes in his hand, while he was bound in chains, and there were no fruits in Mecca at that time." She used to say, "This is sustenance from Allah that He provided for Khubayb." When they went out of the sanctuary to kill him in the open, Khubayb said to them, "Let me pray two rak'ahs." They let him. He prayed two rak'ahs, then said, "Were it not that you would think I was afraid, I would have prolonged it. O Allah, count them and destroy them. Then he recited:
"I do not care when I am killed as a Muslim,
On whichever side it may be for Allah's decree.
And if He wills, He will bless the scattered limbs.
Al-Harith's son killed him. Khubayb was the one who initiated the two rak'ahs for every Muslim who is killed patiently. Allah answered the prayer of Asim bin Thabit when he was struck. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, informed his companions of their news and what had befallen them. Some of the disbelievers of Quraysh sent to Asim, when they heard he was killed, to bring something from him as identification. He had killed one of their great men on the day of Badr. Then, a swarm of wasps, like a canopy, was sent upon Asim, and it protected him from their messengers, so they were unable to cut any of his flesh.

title: The Expedition of Bi'r Ma'unah.
details: Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that Ri'l, Dhakwan, 'Usayyah, and Bani Lihyan sought the help of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, against an enemy. So he sent them seventy of the Ansar, whom we used to call the Qurra' (reciters) in their time. They used to gather firewood during the day and pray at night. Until they reached Bi'r Ma'unah, where they were killed and betrayed. When this news reached the Prophet, peace be upon him, he performed the Qunut for a month, supplicating in the morning prayer against certain tribes of the Arabs, namely Ri'l, Dhakwan, 'Usayyah, and Bani Lihyan. Anas said: "We used to recite a portion of the Quran about them, then that was abrogated: 'Convey from us to our people that we have met our Lord, and He is pleased with us and has pleased us.' And in a narration with Bukhari, it is mentioned that those seventy Ansar were killed at Bi'r Ma'unah. Anas bin Malik also narrated: Some people came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and said: 'Send us men to teach us the Quran and the Sunnah.' So he sent them seventy men from the Ansar, who were called the Qurra'. Among them was my uncle Haram. They used to recite the Quran and study at night to learn. During the day, they would bring water and place it in the mosque, and they would gather firewood, sell it, and buy food with it for the people of the Suffah and the poor. The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent them to those people. They were ambushed and killed before they reached their destination. They said: 'O Allah, convey to our Prophet that we have met You, and we are pleased with You, and You are pleased with us.' It was narrated that a man came up behind Haram, the uncle of Anas, and stabbed him with a spear until it pierced him. Haram said: 'By the Lord of the Ka'bah, I have succeeded!' The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to his companions: 'Your brothers have been killed, and they said: O Allah, convey to our Prophet that we have met You, and we are pleased with You, and You are pleased with us.'"

title: The Expedition of Banu Nadir.
details: The reason for this was that when the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, were killed at the Well of Ma'unah, and they were seventy in number, and 'Amr ibn Umayyah al-Dhamri escaped from them. When he was on his way back to Medina, he killed two men from Banu 'Amir, who had a treaty and a pledge of safety from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, which 'Amr did not know about. When he returned, he informed the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him... So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went out to Banu an-Nadir seeking their help in the blood money for those two men. The dwellings of Banu an-Nadir were outside Medina, a few miles to its east. Muhammad ibn Ishaq ibn Yasar said in his book "Al-Sirah": Then the Messenger of Allah went out to Banu an-Nadir, seeking their help in the blood money for those two killed men from Banu 'Amir, whom 'Amr ibn Umayyah al-Dhamri had killed, due to the protection that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had granted them... When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came to them seeking their help in the blood money for those two killed men, they said: Yes, O Abu al-Qasim, we will help you in whatever you wish and have sought our help for. Then they conferred among themselves and said: You will not find the man in such a situation as this – and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was beside a wall of their houses – so who will go up onto this house and throw a rock at him, and rid us of him? 'Amr ibn Jahsh ibn Ka'b, one of them, volunteered and said: I will do it. So he climbed up to throw a rock at him as they had said, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was with a group of his companions, including Abu Bakr, 'Umar, and 'Ali, may Allah be pleased with them. Then the news came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, from heaven about what the people intended, so he stood up and left, returning to Medina. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, was delayed, his companions went looking for him and met a man coming from Medina. They asked him about him, and he said: I saw him entering Medina. So the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, came back until they reached him, and he informed them of the news of what the Jews had intended to do to him treacherously. And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered them to prepare for war against them and to march towards them. Then he marched until he reached them, and they fortified themselves in their fortresses. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered the cutting down and burning of their palm trees. They called out to him: O Muhammad, you used to forbid corruption and criticize those who did it, so what about cutting down and burning the palm trees?! A group from Banu 'Awf ibn al-Khazraj, including 'Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul, Wardi'ah, Malik ibn Abi Qawqal, Suwayd, and Da'is, had sent to Banu an-Nadir saying: Stand firm and resist, for we will not hand you over. If you are fought, we will fight with you, and if you are expelled, we will go out with you. They waited for this support from them, but it did not come, and Allah cast terror into their hearts. So they asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to expel them and spare their blood, on the condition that they would have whatever their camels could carry of their property, except for the rings. So he agreed. They carried away from their property what the camels could bear, and a man among them would dismantle his house from the frame of his door, place it on the back of his camel, and take it away. So they went out to Khaybar, and some of them went to Syria, leaving the property to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and it was exclusively for the Messenger of Allah. It is confirmed in Sahih al-Bukhari that the Prophet, peace be upon him, expelled Banu an-Nadir. And the Surah Al-Hashr was revealed concerning them.

title: The Battle of Dhat al-Riqa'.
details: Jabir ibn Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, went out to Dhat al-Riqa' from Nakhla. He encountered a gathering of Ghatafan, but there was no fighting. The people frightened each other. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed the prayer of fear. And Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, said: We went out with the Prophet, peace be upon him, on an expedition, and we were six men. We took turns riding a camel. Our feet became blistered, and my feet became blistered, and my fingernails fell off. We used to wrap rags around our feet. So it was named the expedition of Dhat al-Riqa' because of the rags we tied around our feet. Abu Musa narrated this, then he disliked it and said: I wish I had not mentioned it, as if he disliked that anything of his deeds was revealed. And from Salih ibn Khawwat, from one who witnessed the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, praying the prayer of fear on the day of Dhat al-Riqa': A group stood in prayer with him, and another group faced the enemy. He prayed one rak'ah with those who were with him, then he remained standing, and they completed the prayer on their own. Then they departed and stood facing the enemy. The other group came, and he prayed with them the remaining rak'ah of his prayer, then he remained seated, and they completed the prayer on their own, and he gave the salutation with them. This was the expedition against Muharib, Khasafa, and Banu Tha'labah of Ghatafan. And from Jabir ibn Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with them both: The Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed the prayer of fear with his companions in the seventh expedition, the expedition of Dhat al-Riqa'. And from Jabir, he said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, prayed with them on the day of Muharib and Tha'labah.

title: The Battle of Badr al-Maw'id (Second Badr).
details: This expedition is called the Lesser Badr, the Small Badr, the Second Badr, and Badr of the Promise. This is due to the appointment made with Abu Sufyan ibn Harb on the day of Uhud. When Abu Sufyan departed from Uhud, he called out, "Your appointment is Badr, next year." When the fourth year of the Hijra arrived, the Messenger, peace be upon him, set out with fifteen hundred of his companions to Badr, accompanied by ten horses. His banner was carried by Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him. This was in anticipation of the arrival of the Quraysh according to the appointed time set since the Battle of Uhud with Abu Sufyan, the leader of the Quraysh. The Muslims waited for eight days without the Quraysh arriving. Abu Sufyan had set out with two thousand men and fifty horses. When they reached Marr al-Dhuhran, forty miles from Mecca, they turned back, claiming that the year was one of drought. Their breaking of the promise had the effect of strengthening the position of the Muslims and restoring their prestige. The Muslims continued to send their detachments to various parts of Najd and Hijaz to discipline the Bedouins. Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah led a detachment to Tayy and Asad in Najd, and they dispersed into the mountains without any fighting occurring. The Messenger, peace be upon him, led an army of one thousand fighters in the month of Rabi al-Awwal in the fifth year towards Dumat al-Jandal, having been informed of a gathering of polytheists there. However, the gathering dispersed upon learning of the Muslims' arrival. The Muslims stayed in the area for several days, during which they sent out detachments. They encountered no resistance and returned to Medina after making a truce upon their return with Uyaynah ibn Hisn al-Fazari.

title: The Incident of the Lie
details: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, went out to the Banu Mustaliq to wage war against them, he drew lots among his wives to decide who would accompany him. The lot fell upon Aisha, the pure, may Allah be pleased with her. On the journey back, she was carried in a howdah. Allah decreed that on that day, she would be outside her howdah searching for a necklace that had fallen from her. When they intended to depart, they did not realize her absence and left. She was young and light in weight. When she returned, she did not see them. Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said: "I made my way to the place where I had been, thinking that the people would miss me and return for me. While I was sitting in my place, sleep overcame me, and I slept. Safwan ibn al-Mu'attal al-Sulami, then al-Dhukwani, had camped behind the army and traveled at night. He came upon my resting place in the morning and saw the silhouette of a sleeping person. He came to me and recognized me when he saw me, as he had seen me before the veil was imposed upon me. I awoke to his exclamation of recognition. I covered my face with my garment, and by Allah, he did not speak a word to me, nor did I hear a word from him except his exclamation. Then he made his mount kneel, and it stepped on her hand, so I mounted it. He set off, leading the mount with me on it, until we reached the army, after they had dismounted in the heat of noon. So, those who were destroyed were destroyed concerning my affair. The one who bore the greatest part of it was Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul..." They accused her along with Safwan, and this clear slander began to spread in Medina. Aisha remained for a month, knowing nothing of it, until she learned of it directly from Umm Mistah. All this time, the truth had not been clarified. Then verses were revealed, to be recited until the Day of Resurrection, from His saying, the Almighty: {Indeed, those who came with the slander were a group among you. Do not think it evil for you; rather, it is good for you.} [An-Nur: 11] to His saying: {But Allah purifies whom He wills, and Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing.} [An-Nur: 21] Verses that exonerate the pure, the purified, from what the slanderers fabricated.

title: The Expedition of Dumat al-Jandal.
details: The raid on Dumat al-Jandal – a place on the edge of Syria, five nights from it and Damascus, and fifteen or sixteen nights from Medina – took place in Rabi' al-Awwal of the fifth year of the Hijra. Its cause was that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, received news that there was a large gathering of tribes in Dumat al-Jandal, and that they wronged those who passed by them, plundered what they had, and intended to approach Medina to attack it. So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, called the people to arms, and appointed Sibaa' ibn 'Arfatah al-Ghifari as his deputy in Medina. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, set out with a thousand Muslims. They traveled by night and hid by day. With him, peace be upon him, was a guide from Banu 'Udhrah named Madhkur. When they approached Dumat al-Jandal, they attacked their livestock and shepherds, and seized what they could. Those who could, fled in all directions. When the people of Dumat al-Jandal learned of this, they dispersed. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, encamped in their vicinity but found no one there. He stayed for a few days and dispatched scouting parties, which returned without finding anyone. One man was captured. The Messenger of Allah asked him about them, and he replied: "They fled when they heard that you had captured their livestock." The Messenger of Allah offered him Islam, and he accepted. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned to Medina without encountering any opposition.

title: The Battle of Banu al-Mustaliq (al-Muraysi')
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, learned that Banu al-Mustaliq – who were a clan from the Azd Yamani tribe of Khuza'ah – were gathering to fight him. Their leader was Al-Harith ibn Abi Dirar. When the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, heard about them, he marched out to meet them until he encountered them at a watering place of theirs called al-Muraysi'. This is why this expedition is also called the Expedition of al-Muraysi'. The people advanced and fought, and God defeated Banu al-Mustaliq, killing those who were killed among them. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, took their sons, women, and wealth as spoils of war, which God granted him. Among those taken captive was Juwayriyah, may God be pleased with her, the daughter of Al-Harith ibn Abi Dirar, the chief of Banu al-Mustaliq. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, married her when she came to him seeking his help in her manumission contract. He made forty captives from her people her dowry, and the people freed those captives they held because of the status of Juwayriyah, may God be pleased with her. During the return journey from this expedition, the people of slander spoke what they spoke concerning the Mother of the Believers, Aisha, may God be pleased with her, the truthful daughter of the truthful one, who was exonerated from above the seven heavens. In this expedition also, Ibn Ubayy ibn Salul said his statement: "If we return to Medina, the mighty will expel the lowly from it!" Zayd ibn Arqam heard him, and the chapter "Al-Munafiqun" was revealed.

title: The Battle of the Trench (The Confederates)
details:
The cause of this Ghazwah was the expulsion of the Jews of Banu Nadir from Medina. Envy and malice had taken hold of their hearts, causing them to harbor enmity and seek opportunities for revenge against those who had driven them out of Medina and its surroundings. When the Jews of Khaybar, especially Banu Nadir, could not confront the Muslims, they resorted to cunning and incitement. Ibn Ishaq mentioned, with his chain of narration from a group, that those who incited the Confederates were a group of Jews, including: Sallam bin Abi al-Huqayq, Huyayy bin Akhtab al-Nadari, Kinanah bin Abi al-Huqayq al-Nadari, Hawdha bin Qays al-Wa'ili, and Abu Ammar al-Wa'ili, along with a group from Banu Nadir. When they approached Quraysh, they invited them to war against the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and said: "We will be with you against him until we uproot him." Quraysh said to them: "O assembly of Jews, you are the people of the first Scripture and have knowledge of what we and Muhammad differ about. Is our religion better or his?" They replied: "Rather, your religion is better than his, and you are more deserving of the truth than he!!!"

The scholars differed on the timing of this Ghazwah. Bukhari leaned towards the opinion of Musa bin Uqbah that it occurred in Shawwal in the fourth year (of Hijra), while the vast majority held that it was in the fifth year. Al-Dhahabi said: "This is the established view." Ibn al-Qayyim said: "This is the more correct opinion."

The Prophet (peace be upon him) and his companions (may Allah be pleased with them) dug a trench in the exposed area in front of the invaders. Ibn Uqbah mentioned that digging the trench took nearly twenty nights. Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) went out to the trench, and the Muhajirun and Ansar were digging on a cold morning. They had no slaves to do this for them. When he saw their exhaustion and hunger, he said: 'O Allah, verily, life is the life of the Hereafter, so forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirah.' They responded to him, saying: 'We are those who have pledged allegiance to Muhammad... to strive in jihad as long as we live, forever.'"

Al-Bara' (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: "When it was the day of the Confederates, and the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) dug the trench, I saw him carrying dirt from the trench, until the dust covered the skin of his stomach. He was a man with much hair. I heard him reciting the words of Ibn Rawahah, as he carried the dirt, saying: 'By Allah, if not for You, we would not have been guided, nor would we have given charity, nor would we have prayed. So send down tranquility upon us, and make our feet firm if we meet the enemy. Indeed, those who have wronged us have rebelled against us, and if they intended to try us, we would refuse.'" He said: "Then he would extend his voice with the last part of it."

Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said regarding the verse: "{When they came upon you from above you and from below you, and when eyes shifted and hearts reached the throats...}" (Quran 33:10), "That was the day of the trench."

When the Confederates reached Medina, they were surprised by the presence of the trench, and they made several attempts to breach it, but they failed. The siege lasted for twenty-four nights. The situation became difficult for Quraysh due to the wind that overturned their cooking pots and tents. The Muslims also sowed discord between the Jews and the polytheists, forcing them to retreat. Allah the Almighty defeated them and averted their evil from Medina.

title: The revelation of the verse of the hijab.
details: The reason for its revelation was that Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him: "If you would order your wives to veil themselves, for indeed, the righteous and the wicked speak to them." Then the Almighty's saying was revealed: "O you who have believed, do not enter the houses of the Prophet except when you are permitted..." to His saying: "...And when you ask of them [his wives] any material thing, ask them from beyond a partition. That is purer for your hearts and their hearts."

title: The Battle of the Banu Qurayza Jews.
details: This expedition occurred immediately after the Battle of the Trench. Its cause was the breach of the covenant by Banu Qurayzah with the Prophet, peace be upon him, instigated by Huyayy ibn Akhtab an-Nadri. The Prophet, peace be upon him, had sent Zubayr to ascertain their intentions, and then followed him with the two Sa'ds – Sa'd ibn Ubadah and Sa'd ibn Mu'adh – and Ibn Rawahah, and Khawwat ibn Jubayr, for the same purpose, to confirm their treachery. Allah the Almighty commanded His Prophet, peace be upon him, to fight them after his return from the Trench and laying down of arms. So, the Prophet, peace be upon him, instructed his companions to proceed to Banu Qurayzah, saying to them: "Let none of you pray the Asr prayer except in Banu Qurayzah." This is according to the narration of Bukhari, or "Dhuhr" according to the narration of Muslim. The Messenger, peace be upon him, then besieged Banu Qurayzah for approximately twenty-five nights, until they submitted to the judgment of the Messenger, peace be upon him. He wished to entrust their judgment to one of the chiefs of Aws, as they were allies of Banu Qurayzah. Thus, he made Sa'd ibn Mu'adh the judge over them. When he approached the Muslims, the Messenger, peace be upon him, said to the Ansar: "Stand up for your chief – or your best." Then he said: "These have submitted to your judgment." Sa'd ibn Mu'adh said: "Their fighting men shall be killed, their women and children shall be taken captive, and their wealth shall be divided." The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to him: "You have judged with the judgment of Allah the Almighty." The Messenger, peace be upon him, carried out this judgment upon them. They were approximately four hundred in number. Only a few of them escaped. Then the Messenger, peace be upon him, divided their wealth and their children among the Muslims.

title: The killing of Sallam ibn Abi al-Huqayq, the Jew.
details:
He is Abu Rafi', Salam bin Abi al-Huqayq, a Jewish poet and knight, one of those who mobilized the factions against the Muslims in the Battle of the Confederates. He aided them with abundant provisions and wealth. When Allah killed Ka'b bin al-Ashraf at the hands of men from the Aws after the Battle of Badr, Abu Rafi', Salam bin Abi al-Huqayq was among those who incited the Confederates against the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He was not killed with Banu Qurayza as his companion Huyayy bin Akhtab was. The Khazraj desired to kill him, seeking to equalize the Aws in reward. Allah, Glorified and Exalted, had made these two tribes compete in good deeds before the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. They sought permission from the Messenger of Allah to kill him, and he granted them permission.

Al-Bara' bin Azib narrated: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent some men from the Ansar to Abu Rafi' the Jew. He appointed Abdullah bin Atik as their leader. Abu Rafi' used to harm the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and aid against him. He was in a fortress of his in the land of Hijaz. When they approached him, the sun had set, and people were returning with their livestock. Abdullah said to his companions: "Sit where you are, for I am going to approach and try to get close to the gatekeeper, perhaps I can enter." He approached until he was near the gate. Then he covered himself with his garment as if he was relieving himself. As people were entering, the gatekeeper called out to him: "O Abdullah, if you want to enter, then enter, for I am about to close the gate." So I entered and hid. When the people entered, he closed the gate, then hung the locks on a peg. He said: "I went to the keys and took them, and opened the gate." Abu Rafi' used to have evening gatherings. He was in an upper chamber. When his guests left, I went up to him. As I opened each door, I locked it behind me from the inside. I said: "If the people realize I am here, they will not be able to reach me until I kill him." I reached him, and he was in a dark room amidst his family. I did not know where he was in the room. I said: "O Abu Rafi'," he said: "Who is this?" I moved towards the voice and struck him with a sword, in my bewilderment. It did not avail him, and he cried out. I left the room and stayed a short distance away, then I returned to him and said: "What is this sound, O Abu Rafi'?" He said: "Woe to your mother, a man was in the room and struck me with a sword before." He said: "I struck him a blow that wounded him deeply but did not kill him. Then I placed the tip of the sword in his belly until it went through his back. I knew then that I had killed him. I began to open the doors, one by one, until I reached a staircase. I placed my foot, thinking I had reached the ground, and fell on a moonlit night. My leg broke. I tied it with my turban, then I set off until I sat by the door. I said: 'I will not leave tonight until I know if I have killed him.' When the rooster crowed, the announcer stood on the wall and said: 'I announce the death of Abu Rafi', the merchant of the people of Hijaz.' I went to my companions and said: 'Escape! Allah has killed Abu Rafi'.' I went to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and told him. He said: 'Stretch out your leg.' I stretched out my leg, and he wiped it, and it was as if I had never complained of it."

title: The Battle of Dhu Qarad.
details: 'Uyaynah ibn Hisn, among the Banu Abd Allah ibn Ghaṭfan, raided the she-camels of the Prophet, peace be upon him, which were grazing in al-Ghaba. He seized them and killed their shepherd, a man from Ghifar, and they took his wife. The first to raise the alarm against them was Salamah ibn Amr ibn al-Akwa', al-Aslami, may Allah be pleased with him. Salamah said: "I went out before the first call to prayer. The she-camels of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, were grazing at Dhi Qarad. He said: 'A slave of Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf met me and said: "The she-camels of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, have been taken." I asked: "Who took them?" He said: "Ghaṭfan." He said: "So I cried out three times, 'Oh, morning!' I made my voice heard between the two lava fields of Medina. Then I set off at full speed until I caught up with them at Dhi Qarad, as they were beginning to drink from the water. I started pelting them with my arrows, for I was a good archer, and I said: 'I am the son of al-Akwa'... and today is the day of the sucklings.'" I recited poetry until I rescued the she-camels from them, and I took thirty cloaks from them. He said: "Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the people came. I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, I have prevented the people from the water while they were thirsty, so send them now.' He said: 'O son of al-Akwa', you have gained possession, so be lenient.' Then he said: 'They are now being hosted by Ghaṭfan.'" The cry for help in Medina reached the Banu Amr ibn Awf, and reinforcements came. Horses continued to arrive, and men on foot and on camels until they reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, at Dhi Qarad. The Prophet, peace be upon him, reached a watering place called Dhi Qarad. He slaughtered a she-camel from those he had recovered and stayed there for a day and a night, then returned to Medina. In this raid, al-Akhram, who was Muhriz ibn Nadlah, may Allah be pleased with him, was killed. Abd al-Rahman ibn 'Uyaynah killed him and rode away on his horse. Abu Qatadah then charged him and killed him, and recovered the horse, which had belonged to Mahmud ibn Maslamah. The captive woman came on a she-camel of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, having vowed that if Allah saved her upon it, she would slaughter it. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "What a bad reward she has given! A person has no vow for what he does not own, nor for disobedience." And he took back his she-camel. Muslim narrated in his Sahih from Salamah ibn al-Akwa' concerning this incident, saying: "We returned to Medina, and we stayed only three nights until we went out to Khaybar."

title: The expedition of Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may Allah be pleased with him, to al-Qurata.
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may Allah be pleased with him, with thirty riders to Al-Qurṭāʾ – a seven-night journey from Medina. They were a clan of Banu Bakr, and their leader was ʿUbayd ibn Kilāb. Muhammad ibn Maslamah and his companions set out, traveling by night and hiding during the day. When they raided them, the rest fled after Muhammad killed a number of them. The Muslims seized camels and sheep and arrived in Medina on the last night of Muḥarram, bringing with them Thumamah ibn Uthāl al-Ḥanafī, the chief of Banu Ḥanīfah. He had gone out in disguise to assassinate the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, by the order of Musaylimah the Liar. The Muslims captured him, and when they brought him, they tied him to one of the pillars of the Mosque. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, went out to him and said, "What do you have, O Thumamah?" He replied, "I have good, O Muhammad. If you kill, you kill one who has blood [to avenge]. If you bestow favor, you bestow it upon one who is grateful. And if you desire wealth, ask, and you will be given whatever you wish." So he left him. Then he passed by him again and said the same thing to him, and he replied as he had before. Then he passed by a third time and, after the previous conversation, said, "Release Thumamah." So they released him. He went to a palm grove near the Mosque, bathed, then came and embraced Islam. He said, "By Allah, there was no face on the face of the earth more hateful to me than your face, but now your face has become the most beloved of faces to me. And by Allah, there was no religion on the face of the earth more hateful to me than your religion, but now your religion has become the most beloved of religions to me. Your cavalry captured me while I intended to perform ʿUmrah." The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gave him glad tidings and ordered him to perform ʿUmrah. When he arrived among the Quraysh, they said, "Have you apostatized, O Thumamah?" He said, "No, by Allah, but I have embraced Islam with Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. And by Allah, not a single grain of wheat will come to you from Yamāmah unless the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, permits it." Yamāmah was the fertile region of Mecca. He returned to his land and prevented the transport of goods to Mecca until the Quraysh were in dire straits. They wrote to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, imploring him by their kinship ties to write to Thumamah to allow them to transport food. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did so.

title: The expedition of Ukashah ibn Mihsan (may Allah be pleased with him) to al-Ghamr (the water of Banu Asad).
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Ukkasha ibn Mihsan, may Allah be pleased with him, to Al-Ghamr – a water source belonging to Banu Asad – with forty men, including Thabit ibn Aqram and Shuja ibn Wahb. They set out quickly, but the people were alerted and fled to the higher ground of their land. He found their dwellings empty, meaning their inhabitants were absent. He then sent Shuja ibn Wahb as a scout. He saw tracks of camels and sheep. They moved on and found someone who guided them to some of their livestock. They granted him safety, and he led them to camels belonging to his cousins. They raided them and seized two hundred camels. They sent the man back and drove the camels to Medina. They arrived at the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, without encountering any harm.

title: The expedition of Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Tha'labah and Banu 'Awal at Dhi al-Qassah.
details: The Messenger of God, Muhammad, peace be upon him, sent Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may God be pleased with him, along with ten men, to Banu Tha'labah of Ghatafan and Banu 'Awalin of Tha'labah, who were at Dhi al-Qassah. They arrived upon them at night, and the people surrounded them. They were one hundred men. They exchanged arrows for a while during the night, then the Arabs attacked them with spears and killed them all. Muhammad ibn Maslamah fell wounded. They struck his ankle, and he did not move, so they thought he was dead. They stripped him of his clothes and left. A Muslim man passed by Muhammad and his companions and uttered "Indeed, to God we belong and to Him we shall return." When Muhammad heard him saying this, he moved. The man took him and carried him to Medina. At that point, the Messenger of God, Muhammad, peace be upon him, sent Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah with forty men to the place where they fell. They found no one, but they found camels and sheep, and they drove them to Medina.

title: The expedition of Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah to Dhi al-Qassah.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah, may God be pleased with him, to Dhi al-Qassah – a place near Medina – in the aftermath of the killing of the companions of Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may God be pleased with him, along with forty Muslims, as they were performing the Maghrib prayer. He marched to them on foot until they reached Dhi al-Qassah at the break of dawn – the remaining darkness of the night. They raided them, but they escaped into the mountains, eluding them. They captured one man who embraced Islam, so they left him. They also seized some of their livestock and scattered household items. They brought these back to Medina. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, took one-fifth of the spoils and distributed the rest among them. Ibn Sa'd states in his Tabaqat that the reason for sending Abu Ubaidah, may God be pleased with him, to Dhi al-Qassah was the news that Banu Muharib ibn Khasfah, Tha'labah, and Anmar – who are from Ghatafan – had agreed to raid the livestock of Medina as it grazed at Hayfa, a place seven miles from Medina. It is possible that the Messenger, peace be upon him, sent Abu Ubaidah, may God be pleased with him, to Dhi al-Qassah twice, or that the expedition was a single event with two reasons: to avenge the slain companions of Muhammad ibn Maslamah, may God be pleased with him, and to repel those who intended to raid the livestock of Medina.

title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, to al-Jumum (a watering place on the road to Mecca).
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Sulaym. He traveled until he reached al-Jamum – which is a watering place on the road to Mecca, to the left of Batn Nakhla. There, they encountered a woman from Muzaynah, named Halimah. She guided them to a settlement of Banu Sulaym. In that settlement, they seized camels, sheep, and captives. Among the captives was the husband of Halimah al-Muzayniyyah. When Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, returned to Medina with what he had acquired, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, granted Halimah herself and her husband to her.

title: The Expedition against Banu Lihyan (who betrayed on the Day of Ar-Raj'i).
details: Banu Lihyan: They were the ones who betrayed Khubayb ibn Adi, may Allah be pleased with him, and his companions on the Day of Ar-Raji. Since their lands extended deep into the Hijaz region, bordering Mecca, and due to existing feuds between the Muslims on one side, and Quraysh and the Bedouins on the other, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, deemed it unwise to venture into lands close to the greatest and primary enemy, Quraysh. When the confederates faltered and their resolve weakened, he saw that the time had come to raid Banu Lihyan and avenge the companions of Ar-Raji. So, the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, marched out to them with two hundred of his companions, seeking retribution for the blood of his companions, accompanied by twenty horses. He appointed Abdullah ibn Umm Maktum, may Allah be pleased with him, as his deputy in Medina. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, gave the impression that he intended to go to Sham to catch Banu Lihyan by surprise. Then he hastened his march until he reached Wadi Ghurran, between Amj - a place between Mecca and Medina - and Usfan - a village between Mecca and Medina. These were the dwelling places of Banu Lihyan, and where his companions had met their fate. He prayed for mercy upon them and supplicated for them. Banu Lihyan heard of his arrival, so they fled and took refuge in the mountain peaks. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, could not reach any of them. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stayed in their land for a day or two, and sent out raiding parties in every direction, but they could not capture anyone. Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, marched with his companions to Usfan, so that Quraysh would hear of it and be filled with dread, and to show them his strength. He sent Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, with ten horsemen to Kur al-Ghamim - a place between Mecca and Medina. Then Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, returned without encountering anyone.

title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, to Al-ʿĪṣ.
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, in a detachment of one hundred and seventy riders to Al-`Is, a place near Medina on the coast of the sea, with the aim of intercepting a caravan of Quraysh that was coming from Syria, led by Abu Al-`As ibn Al-Rabi`. They caught up with it, seized it and what was in it, and that day they took much silver belonging to Safwan ibn Umayyah. They also captured people from among those who were in the caravan, including Abu Al-`As ibn Al-Rabi`, and brought them to Medina. Abu Al-`As was among the distinguished men of Mecca in terms of trade, wealth, and trustworthiness. He was the husband of Zaynab, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. His mother was Halah bint Khuwaylid, the sister of Khadijah, may Allah be pleased with her. Abu Al-`As came to Zaynab, may Allah be pleased with her, at night. Zaynab had migrated before him, leaving him in his polytheism. He sought her protection, and she granted him protection. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, approved her protection.

title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah to Banu Tha'labah at al-Tarf (a watering place near Medina).
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Zayd ibn Harithah, may Allah be pleased with him, to Al-Taraf – which is a watering place thirty-six miles from Medina. He went out to Banu Tha'labah with fifteen men. The Arabs fled, fearing that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, had marched against them, and that these men were a vanguard. He seized twenty camels from their livestock and returned to Medina without encountering any opposition. He was away for four nights. Their war cry was: "Kill, kill."

title: The Expedition of Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf, may Allah be pleased with him, to Dumat al-Jandal.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, called Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf, may God be pleased with him, and said to him: "Prepare yourself, for I am sending you on a mission from this day, or tomorrow if God Almighty wills." Abd al-Rahman awoke and went to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, who seated him before him and turbaned him with his own hand. Then the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, tied the banner with his own hand, or ordered Bilal to hand it to him, and then said to him: "Take it in the name of God and His blessings." Then he praised God Almighty, and then the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "Go forth in the name of God and in the cause of God, and fight those who disbelieve in God! Do not commit treachery – treachery is betrayal in spoils of war and theft from the booty before distribution – do not break your covenant, and do not kill a child." Then the Messenger of God ordered him to march to the tribe of Banu Kalb in Dumat al-Jandal, and to invite them to Islam. He said to him: "If they respond to you, then marry their king's daughter." Abd al-Rahman, may God be pleased with him, marched with his companions, who numbered seven hundred men, until he reached Dumat al-Jandal. He stayed there for three days, inviting them to Islam. When the third day came, their chief and king, al-Asbagh ibn Amr al-Kalbi, who was a Christian, embraced Islam, and many of his people embraced Islam with him. Abd al-Rahman then sent Rafi' ibn Makith as a bearer of good news to the Prophet, peace be upon him, informing him of the victory God had granted him and writing to him about it. Abd al-Rahman married Tamadir bint al-Asbagh and brought her to Medina. She later bore him Abu Salamah ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf.

title: The expedition of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Fazara in Wadi al-Qura.
details: The clan of Fazara intended to assassinate the Prophet, peace be upon him. So, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment led by Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may God be pleased with him. They raided them, killing, capturing, and taking spoils. Among their notorious figures was Umm Qirfa, who had prepared thirty horsemen from her household to assassinate the Messenger of God, peace be upon him. They were killed, and her daughter was captured. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, ransomed some Muslim captives in Mecca with her. Imam Muslim narrated in his Sahih from Salamah bin Al-Akwa', may God be pleased with him, who said: "We went on an expedition against Fazara, and Abu Bakr was our commander, appointed by the Messenger of God, peace be upon him. When we were an hour away from the water, Abu Bakr ordered us to encamp. Then he launched the raid and reached the water. He killed those he killed there and took captives. I saw a group of people, including children, and I feared they would reach the mountain before me, so I shot an arrow between them and the mountain. When they saw the arrow, they stopped. I brought them, driving them. Among them was a woman from Banu Fazara wearing a garment of tanned leather (meaning a leather garment), with her was a daughter, one of the most beautiful Arab women. I drove them until I brought them to Abu Bakr, and Abu Bakr gave me her daughter as a spoil. When we arrived in Medina, I had not uncovered her. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, met me in the market and said: 'O Salamah, gift me the woman.' I said: 'O Messenger of God, by God, she has pleased me, and I have not uncovered her.' The next day, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, met me again in the market and said to me: 'O Salamah, gift me the woman, may your father be sacrificed for you!' I said: 'She is yours, O Messenger of God, and by God, I have not uncovered her.' So, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent her to the people of Mecca, and with her, he ransomed some Muslims who had been captured in Mecca."

title: The Expedition of Kurz ibn Jabir al-Fihri to the 'Arniyyin.
details:
In this year, the expedition of Kurz ibn Jabir al-Fihri took place against the Uraynah tribe. These were the ones who killed the shepherd of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and drove away the livestock. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Kurz ibn Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, with twenty horsemen in pursuit of them.

Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated that a group from Ukl and Uraynah came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and said: "We are people of milk-producing animals, and we are not people of fertile land. The climate of Medina did not suit us." So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered for them a herd of camels and a shepherd, and instructed them to go out with them and drink from their urine and milk. They set off, and when they reached the area of Al-Harrah, they killed the shepherd of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and drove away the herd. They renounced Islam after having embraced it.

The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent out in pursuit of them. He ordered that their hands and feet be cut off, and their eyes be branded with hot iron nails. He left them in the area of Al-Harrah until they died in that state. The reason their eyes were branded was because they had branded the eyes of the shepherds.

title: The Pledge of Ridwan.
details:
Before the conclusion of the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had sent Khirash ibn Umayyah al-Khuzai to Mecca, riding his camel named al-Tha'lab. When he entered Mecca, Quraysh hamstrung his camel and intended to kill Khirash, but the Ahābīsh (who were Banu al-Harith ibn Abd Manah ibn Kinanah, al-Hawn ibn Khuzaymah ibn Mudrikah, and Banu al-Mustaliq from Khuzā'ah) prevented them until he reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He then called for Umar to send him to Mecca. Umar said, "O Messenger of Allah, I fear Quraysh for myself, and there is no one from Banu Adi here to protect me. Quraysh know my enmity towards them and my harshness against them. However, I can direct you to a man who is more honored than I, Uthman ibn Affan." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, called for Uthman and sent him to Quraysh to inform them that he had not come for war, but as a visitor to this House, honoring its sanctity. Uthman set out until he reached Mecca, where Aban ibn Sa'id ibn al-'As met him. Aban dismounted his mount, placed Uthman before him and behind him on his mount, and gave him protection until he delivered the message of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. Uthman then went to Abu Sufyan and the dignitaries of Quraysh and conveyed to them what the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had sent him with. They said to Uthman, "If you wish, you may circumambulate the Kaaba." He replied, "I would not do so until the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, circumambulates it." Quraysh then detained him. It reached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and the Muslims that Uthman had been killed.

Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Pledge of Ridwan took place after Uthman had gone to Mecca. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, placed his right hand on his left hand and said, "This is the hand of Uthman," and struck it with his hand, saying, "This is for Uthman." Jabir ibn Abdullah said: On the day of Hudaybiyyah, we were one thousand and four hundred. We pledged allegiance to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and Umar was holding his hand under the tree, which was a samurah tree. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said to us, "Today, you are the best people on earth." Then Jabir said: If I were able to see, I would show you the location of the tree.

Ma'qil ibn Yasar said: I saw myself on the day of the tree, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, was taking the pledge from the people, and I was holding up a branch of it over his head, and we were fourteen hundred.

The narrations differ regarding their number. Ibn Hajar said: The reconciliation between these differences is that they were more than one thousand and four hundred. Whoever said one thousand and five hundred accounted for the fraction, and whoever said one thousand and four hundred disregarded it.

title: The Treaty of Hudaybiyyah.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, went out with about fourteen hundred of his companions, intending to perform Umrah. When they reached Al-Hudaybiyyah, which is about 22 km from Mecca, news reached him that there were those who intended to fight him. He said: "I have not come for fighting; rather, I have come for Umrah." The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Uthman ibn Affan to Mecca to inform them of this. Then the news spread that Uthman had been killed. So the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, ordered the companions, may God be pleased with them, to pledge allegiance to him for fighting, and they pledged allegiance to him. This was the Pledge of Ridwan. Then the polytheists came to Al-Hudaybiyyah, and several negotiations took place between the leaders of the polytheists and the Prophet, peace be upon him, until Suhail ibn Amr came, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, made peace with him on the condition that war would be suspended for ten years, during which people would be safe and refrain from harming each other. It was also agreed that whoever came to the Messenger of God from his companions without the permission of his guardian, the Messenger of God would return him to them, and whoever came to the Quraysh from his companions, they would not return him. And that there would be a sealed chest between them, meaning no deceit. And that there would be no stealing or treachery. And that he would return in this year without entering Mecca, but he would be allowed to enter it for three days in the following year, with the weapons of a traveler, and not to enter it without swords in their sheaths. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, ordered his companions to sacrifice their animals and shave their heads, but they did not do so until Umm Salamah, may God be pleased with her, advised him to do it himself without speaking to anyone. When they saw him sacrifice, they rushed to the sacrificial animals and did the same. Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, returned to Medina without performing Umrah and without fighting.

title: The Battle of Khaybar.
details:
The historians differ regarding its timing, with two opinions. It was said: in the seventh year. This is the opinion of Ibn Ishaq and others. And it was said: in the sixth year. This is the opinion of Malik and others. Ibn al-Qayyim said: The majority hold that it was in the seventh year. Ibn Hajar said: These opinions are close, and the most likely among them is what Ibn Ishaq mentioned. It is possible to reconcile them by saying that whoever stated the sixth year did so based on the beginning of the year from the actual month of the Hijra, which is Rabi' al-Awwal.

Anas narrated: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went on an expedition to Khaybar. He said: "We prayed the dawn prayer there in the early morning darkness. Then the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, mounted, and Abu Talha mounted, and I was riding behind Abu Talha. The Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, rode through a narrow alley of Khaybar, and my knee was touching the thigh of the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him. The lower garment of the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, slipped, and I saw the whiteness of the thigh of the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him. When he entered the town, he said: 'Allahu Akbar! Khaybar is ruined! When we descend upon a people's courtyard, then it is a bad morning for those who are warned.' He said this three times. He said: The people had gone out to their work, and they said: 'Muhammad! By Allah!' (Abdul Aziz said: And some of our companions said: 'Muhammad and the army'). He said: 'And we conquered it by force. The captives were gathered. Then Dihya came to him and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, give me a slave girl from the captives.' He said: 'Go and take a slave girl.' So he took Safiyyah bint Huyayy. Then a man came to the Prophet of Allah, peace be upon him, and said: 'O Prophet of Allah, you gave Safiyyah bint Huyayy, the chief of Qurayzah and an-Nadir, to Dihya! She is only fit for you.' He said: 'Call him with her.' He said: 'So he brought her. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, looked at her, he said: 'Take a slave girl from the captives other than her.' He said: 'And he freed her and married her...'"

Anas, may Allah be pleased with him, narrated: The Prophet, peace be upon him, went out to Khaybar. He came to it at night. When he came to a people at night, he would not attack them until morning. When morning came, the Jews came out with their shovels and baskets. When they saw him, they said: "Muhammad! By Allah! Muhammad and the army!" Then the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Allahu Akbar! Khaybar is ruined! When we descend upon a people's courtyard, then it is a bad morning for those who are warned." And Allah Almighty made the conquest of Khaybar at the hands of Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him.

Abdullah ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, gave Khaybar to the Jews to work it and cultivate it, and they would have half of what came out of it. So the Prophet, peace be upon him, let them remain in their land, and they would have half.

title: The prohibition of the flesh of domestic donkeys and the temporary marriage of women on the day of Khaybar.
details: During the Battle of Khaybar, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prohibited the meat of domestic donkeys, stating that it was an impurity. He ordered that the pots be thrown away while they were boiling with their meat, and he later ordered the pots to be washed. At that time, he permitted the meat of horses and fed it to them. He also prohibited temporary marriage (mut'ah) of women.

title: The Hijra of Abu Musa al-Ash'ari and his companions, may Allah be pleased with them, to Medina, passing through Abyssinia.
details: Abu Musa (may Allah be pleased with him) reported: News of the departure of the Prophet (peace be upon him) reached us while we were in Yemen. So, my two brothers and I, I being the youngest, set out as emigrants to him. One of them was Abu Burda, and the other was Abu Ruhm. He said, "Either in a few, or he said, in fifty-three, or fifty-two men from my people." We boarded a ship, and our ship cast us ashore to the Negus in Abyssinia. We met Ja'far bin Abi Talib and his companions there. Ja'far said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent us here and commanded us to stay, so stay with us." We stayed with him until we all arrived. We met the Prophet (peace be upon him) when he conquered Khaybar. He gave us a share of it – or he said, he gave us from it. He did not distribute anything from it to anyone who was absent from the conquest of Khaybar, except to those who witnessed it with him, except for the companions of our ship with Ja'far and his companions; he distributed to them along with them.

title: The Jews' attempt to poison the Messenger of God, peace be upon him.
details: When the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, felt secure in Khaybar after its conquest, Zaynab bint al-Harith, the wife of Sallam ibn Mishkam, presented him with a roasted sheep. She had inquired which part of the sheep the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, preferred, and was told it was the foreleg. She then put a large amount of poison in it, and also poisoned the rest of the sheep. She brought it to him, and when she placed it before the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, he took the foreleg and chewed a morsel from it, but he could not swallow it and spat it out. Then he said, "This bone informs me that it is poisoned." He then called for her, and she confessed. He asked, "What drove you to do this?" She replied, "I thought if he were a king, we would be rid of him, and if he were a prophet, he would be informed." He pardoned her. Bishr ibn al-Bara' ibn Ma'rur was with him and ate a portion of it, which he swallowed. He died from it. There are differing narrations regarding the pardon of the woman and her execution. They agree that he initially pardoned her, but when Bishr died, he killed her in retribution.

title: The Prophet's correspondence with the kings, inviting them to Islam.
details: After the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, returned from Al-Hudaybiyyah, he wrote to the kings, inviting them to Islam. When he intended to write to them, it was said to him, "They do not read a letter unless it has a seal on it." So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, took a silver ring, the engraving of which was: "Muhammad, Messenger of Allah." This engraving was in three lines: "Muhammad" on one line, "Messenger" on another, and "Allah" on a third. Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I can almost see the gleam of the ring on the Prophet's finger - or on his palm." He chose messengers from his companions who had knowledge and experience and sent them to the kings. He sent Dihyah bin Khalifa Al-Kalbi to Caesar, the King of Rome, who read the letter but did not embrace Islam. He sent Abdullah bin Hudhafah As-Sahmi to Khosrow, the King of Persia, who tore the letter to pieces when it was read to him. When this reached the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: "May Allah tear his kingdom apart." And so it was. He sent Amr bin Umayyah Ad-Damri to Al-Najashi, the King of Abyssinia. When he gave him the letter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, he took it, placed it on his eyes, and descended from his throne to the ground. He sent Hatib bin Abi Balta'ah to Al-Muqawqis, the ruler of Alexandria. He took the Prophet's letter, placed it in an ivory box, sealed it, and then wrote a letter to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, but did not embrace Islam. He gifted him two slave women, Maria and Shireen, and a mule named Dul-dul. He sent Amr bin Al-As As-Sahmi to Ja'far and 'Abbad, the sons of Al-Julanda Al-Azdiyyin, the kings of Oman. They both responded to Islam and believed in the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. He sent Sulait bin Amr, one of the Bani Amir bin Lu'ayy, to Hawdha bin Ali Al-Hanafi, the King of Yamamah, who gave a lukewarm response. He wrote to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: "How excellent and beautiful is what you call to. The Arabs respect my position, so grant me some authority and I will follow you." He sent Al-Ala' bin Al-Hadrami to Al-Mundhir bin Sawa Al-Abdi, the King of Bahrain, who embraced Islam upon receiving the letter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. He sent Shuja' bin Wahb Al-Asadi to Al-Harith bin Abi Shimr Al-Ghassani, the King of the Syrian borders. When the letter reached him, he threw it away and said, "Who will take my kingdom from me? I am marching to him." He did not embrace Islam. He sought permission from Caesar to fight the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, but Caesar dissuaded him from his resolve. Al-Harith, however, rewarded Shuja' bin Wahb with clothing and provisions and sent him back with kindness. He sent Al-Miqdad bin Al-Aswad Al-Makhzumi to Al-Harith bin Abd Kulal Al-Himayri, the King of Yemen, who had already embraced Islam along with his brothers.

title: The expedition of Ghalib ibn Abdullah al-Laythi to the Banu al-Mulawwah at Qudayd.
details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, sent a detachment led by Ghalib ibn Abdullah al-Laythi to the Banu al-Mulawwah in Qudayd. The Banu al-Mulawwah had killed the companions of Bashir ibn Suwayd, so this detachment was sent to exact revenge. They launched a night raid, killing whom they killed and seizing livestock. A large enemy army pursued them until, as they neared the Muslims, rain fell, and a great flood came between the two groups. The Muslims succeeded in completing their withdrawal.

title: The expedition of Zayd ibn Harithah to the land of Hisma.
details: The Messenger, peace be upon him, sent a letter to Caesar of Rome. The bearer of the letter was Dihyah ibn Khalifah al-Kalbi. When Caesar did what he did, he rewarded Dihyah ibn Khalifah al-Kalbi with money and clothing. As Dihyah was on the road in Hisma, some people from Judham encountered him and robbed him, leaving him with nothing. Dihyah came to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, before entering his house and informed him. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Zayd ibn Harithah to Hisma, which is beyond Wadi al-Qura, with five hundred men. Zayd launched a raid against Judham, killing many of them and seizing their camels, sheep, and captives. He took a thousand camels, five thousand sheep, and one hundred women and children as captives. There was a truce between the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the tribe of Judham. Zayd ibn Rifaa'ah al-Judhami, one of the leaders of this tribe, quickly presented a protest to the Prophet, peace be upon him. He and some men from his people had embraced Islam and had helped Dihyah when his way was blocked. The Prophet, peace be upon him, accepted his protest and ordered the return of the spoils and the captives.

title: The expedition of Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, to Turbah, a group of Hawazin.
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, with thirty men to the rear of Hawazin – a place between him and Mecca, four nights away on the road to Sana'a, called Turbah. And Allah's peace be upon him sent a guide from Banu Hilal. He would travel by night and hide by day. The news reached Hawazin, so they fled. Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, came to their encampments and found no one from them, so he returned to Medina.
