When he was six miles between him and Medina, the guide said to him, "Do you have another gathering from Khath'am?" Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said to him, "The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, did not order me to [fight] them; he only ordered me to fight Hawazin."

title: The expedition of Bashir ibn Sa'd al-Ansari to Banu Murrah in the region of Fadak.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment led by Bashir ibn Sa'd al-Ansari to Banu Murrah in the vicinity of Fadak, consisting of thirty men. They went out to them and seized sheep and camels. Then they returned, and the pursuers caught up with them at night. They shot arrows at them until Bashir and his companions ran out of arrows, and they were all killed except for Bashir. He was carried to Fadak with a flicker of life remaining, and he stayed with the Jews until his wounds healed, then he returned to Medina.

title: The expedition of Ghalib ibn Abd Allah al-Laythi to Banu Uwal.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment led by Ghalib ibn Abd Allah al-Laythi to Banu 'Uwal and Banu 'Abd ibn Tha'labah in al-Mayfa'ah, and it is said to the Hurqat of Juhaynah, consisting of one hundred and thirty men. They raided them all, killed those who came out to them, and seized camels and sheep. In this detachment, Usamah ibn Zayd killed Nahik ibn Mirdas after he said, "There is no god but Allah." When they returned and the Prophet, peace be upon him, was informed, he was greatly displeased and said, "Did you kill him after he said, 'There is no god but Allah'?" Usamah replied, "He only said it seeking refuge." The Prophet then said, "Did you not split open his heart to know if he was truthful or lying?"

title: The expedition of Abdullah ibn Rawahah to Khaybar to kill the Jew Yassir ibn Razzam.
details: It reached the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, that Yasir bin Rizam the Jew was gathering Ghatafan to invade Medina. So, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Abdullah bin Rawahah with thirty riders to Yasir bin Rizam until they reached him in Khaybar. They said to him: "The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, has sent us to you to appoint you over Khaybar." They persisted with him until he followed them with thirty men, each man accompanied by a Muslim rider. When they reached Qarqaratu Niyar, Yasir bin Rizam regretted it and reached for the sword of Abdullah bin Rawahah. Abdullah bin Rawahah noticed this, urged his camel forward, and charged, leading the men until he was able to reach Yasir and struck his leg, severing it. Yasir then charged, and in his hand was a whip made of acacia wood, with which he struck Abdullah bin Rawahah's face, inflicting a severe wound that reached the skull. Each of the Muslim men turned to his rider and killed him, except for one Jew who outran them in speed and did not harm any of the Muslims. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, spat into Abdullah bin Rawahah's wound, and it did not fester or cause him pain until he died.

title: The expedition of Abu Hadrad al-Aslami to al-Ghaba.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment led by Abu Hadrad al-Aslami to al-Ghaba. The reason for this was that a man from Jusham ibn Mu'awiyah had arrived in al-Ghaba with a large number of people, intending to rally Qays to fight the Muslims. So, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Abu Hadrad with two men to gather intelligence and information about them. They reached the people at sunset. Abu Hadrad hid in one area, and his companions hid in another. Their shepherd was delayed until the darkness of night fell. The leader of the people then stood up alone. As he passed by Abu Hadrad, Abu Hadrad shot him with an arrow in the heart, and he fell without speaking. Abu Hadrad then beheaded him and rushed towards the camp, shouting "Allahu Akbar." His companions also shouted "Allahu Akbar" and rushed forward. The people had no choice but to flee, and the three Muslims drove off a large number of camels and sheep.

title: The Umrah of Hudaybiyyah, also known as the Umrah of Fulfillment.
details: Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his companions arrived in Mecca, weakened by the fever of Yathrib. The polytheists said: "Tomorrow, a people will come to you weakened by fever, having suffered greatly from it." So they sat down next to the Hijr. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, ordered them to perform *ramal* (a brisk walk) for three circuits and to walk between the two corners, so that the polytheists would see their strength. The polytheists said: "These are the ones you claimed were weakened by fever; they are stronger than so-and-so." Ibn Abbas said: Nothing prevented him from ordering them to perform *ramal* for all the circuits except his concern for them. And in this Umrah, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, married Maymunah bint Al-Harith, may Allah be pleased with her.

title: The expedition of Ibn Abi al-Awja' to Banu Sulaym.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent the detachment of Ibn Abi Al-Awja' to Banu Sulaym, with fifty men, to invite them to Islam. They said, "We have no need for what you have invited us to," and then they fought fiercely. Abu Al-Awja' was wounded in it, and two men from the enemy were captured.

title: The passing of Zaynab, may Allah be pleased with her, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.
details: She is Zaynab, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and the eldest of her sisters. Her cousin, Abu al-As ibn al-Rabi', married her during her mother's lifetime. She bore him Umamah, whom Ali ibn Abi Talib married after Fatima, and she bore him Ali ibn Abi al-As. Zaynab embraced Islam and migrated six years before her husband embraced Islam. Umm Atiyyah said: When Zaynab, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, died, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to us: "Wash her an odd number of times, three or five, and in the fifth time, put camphor, or something of camphor. When you finish washing her, inform me." She said: "We informed him, and he gave us his lower garment and said: 'Put it next to her skin.'"

title: The Expedition of Awṭās (a valley between Mecca and Ta'if).
details: When the Prophet, peace be upon him, finished with Hunayn, he sent Abu 'Amir with an army to Awṭas. They encountered Durayd ibn al-Ṣimmah, and Durayd was killed, and Allah defeated his companions. Abu Musa al-Ash'ari said: "Abu 'Amir 'Ubayd al-Ash'ari sent me with him. Abu 'Amir was wounded in his knee by an arrow shot by a Jushami, which struck him in the knee. I reached him and asked, 'Uncle, who shot you?' He pointed to him and said, 'That is my killer who shot me.' I went for him and caught up with him. When he saw me, he turned to flee, so I pursued him, saying, 'Are you not ashamed? Why don't you stand your ground?' He stopped, and we exchanged two sword blows, and I killed him. Then I said to Abu 'Amir, 'May Allah kill your companion.' He said, 'Pull this arrow out.' I pulled it out, and water gushed forth. He said, 'Nephew, give my greetings to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and tell him to ask for my forgiveness.' Abu 'Amir appointed me as his successor over the people. He remained for a short while and then died. I returned and entered upon the Prophet, peace be upon him, in his house. He was lying on a worn-out bed with a mattress, and the rough fibers of the bed had left marks on his back and sides. I informed him of our news and the news of Abu 'Amir. He said, 'Tell him to ask for my forgiveness.' He then called for water, performed ablution, raised his hands, and said, 'O Allah, forgive 'Ubayd, Abu 'Amir.' I saw the whiteness of his armpits. Then he said, 'O Allah, make him on the Day of Resurrection above many of Your creation among mankind.' I said, 'And appoint me, and forgive me.' He said, 'O Allah, forgive the sin of 'Abd Allah ibn Qays, and admit him on the Day of Resurrection into a noble entrance.' Abu Burda said: 'One of these supplications was for Abu 'Amir, and the other was for Abu Musa.'"

title: The Islam of Amr ibn al-As, Khalid ibn al-Walid, and Uthman ibn Talhah, may Allah be pleased with them.
details: Khalid ibn al-Walid said: "When Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, willed the good He willed for me, He cast Islam into my heart and guided my reason. I said, 'I have witnessed all these battles against Muhammad, peace be upon him, and there was no battle I witnessed except that I would leave feeling that I was in the wrong, and that Muhammad would prevail.' When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, went out to Hudaybiyyah, I went out with the polytheists' cavalry. I stood opposite him in 'Usfan and confronted him. He prayed the Dhuhr prayer with his companions in front of us, and we intended to raid them, but we were not able to. Then he prayed the Asr prayer with his companions, the prayer of fear, and that had a significant impact on us. I said, 'This man is protected.' So we parted ways. When he made peace with Quraysh at Hudaybiyyah, and then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, entered Mecca for the 'Umrah of Qada', he asked for me but did not find me. He wrote me a letter saying: 'In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. To proceed, I have not seen anything more astonishing than your opinion turning away from Islam and your intellect. Would anyone be ignorant of something like Islam?' Then he inquired about me, and it was said to him, 'Allah will bring him.' He said, 'Someone like him being ignorant of Islam, and if he were to strike the polytheists alongside the Muslims, it would be better for him, and we would have preferred him over others.' When his letter reached me, I was eager to go out, and it increased my desire for Islam. I was pleased that he inquired about me. When I decided to go out to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, I met Uthman ibn Talhah and offered him Islam, and he responded quickly. He went out with me until we reached al-Haddah, where we found Amr ibn al-'As. He said, 'Welcome, O people.' We said, 'And to you.' He asked, 'Where are you headed?' We said, 'To enter Islam and follow Muhammad, peace be upon him.' He said, 'And that is what brought me here.' So we accompanied each other until we entered Medina. I put on some of my best clothes, then I went to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He had been informed of our arrival and was pleased. He kept smiling when he saw me until I stood before him. I greeted him with prophethood, and he responded with a cheerful face. I said, 'I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and that you are the Messenger of Allah.' He said, 'Praise be to Allah who has guided you. I used to think you had a mind, and I hoped He would not lead you astray except to good.' I said, 'O Messenger of Allah, you have seen what I used to witness in those battles against you. So pray to Allah to forgive them for me.' The Prophet, peace be upon him, said, 'Islam erases what came before it.'"

title: The expedition of Ghalib ibn Abd Allah al-Laythi to the companions of Bashir ibn Sa'd at Fidak.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent an expedition led by Ghalib bin Abdullah to the injured companions of Bashir bin Sa'd in Fadak, with two hundred men. They seized camels from Banu Murrah and killed some of them.

title: The expedition of Ka'b ibn 'Umayr al-Anṣārī to Banū Kuḍāʿah.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent a detachment to Dhat Atlah under the command of Ka'b ibn 'Umayr al-Ansari with fifteen men to Banu Qudha'ah. This was because they had gathered large numbers to raid the Muslims. They encountered the enemy and invited them to Islam, but they did not respond and showered them with arrows until all of them were killed except for one man, who was recovered from among the slain.

title: The expedition of Shuja' ibn Wahb, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Hawazin.
details: The Banu Hawazin had repeatedly extended a helping hand to the enemies of the Muslims. So, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Shuja' ibn Wahb al-Asadi with twenty-five men to them. They were at al-Siyy, in the vicinity of Rukbah, beyond the mine, which is five nights' journey from Medina. He ordered him to raid them. So, he traveled by night and hid by day until he surprised them while they were heedless. He had instructed his companions not to pursue them excessively. They captured a large number of camels and sheep without encountering any resistance, and drove them until they arrived in Medina and divided the spoils. Each man received fifteen camels, and they valued a camel at ten sheep. Their absence lasted fifteen nights.

title: The Battle of Mu'tah.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, dispatched a detachment of three thousand fighters, with Zayd ibn Harithah as their commander. If he were killed, then Ja'far ibn Abi Talib would take command, and if he were killed, then Abdullah ibn Rawahah would take command. The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, saw them off and bid them farewell, then he returned. The army set out. When they reached Ma'an in the land of Sham, the news reached them that Heraclius, the king of Rome, had descended upon the land of Bani Ma'ab – the land of Balqa – with one hundred thousand Romans and another hundred thousand from the Christians of Sham. The Muslims stayed in Ma'an for two nights, consulting about engaging their enemy, who numbered two hundred thousand. They said, "Let us write to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, to inform him of the number of our enemy, so that he may command us or send us reinforcements." Abdullah ibn Rawahah said, "O people, what you dislike is what you set out to seek – meaning martyrdom. We do not fight people with numbers or strength; rather, we fight them with this [faith] with which God has honored us. So, march forth, for it is one of two good outcomes: either victory or martyrdom." The army agreed with this opinion and set out. When they reached the borders of Balqa, they encountered some of the legions with Heraclius near a village called Mu'tah. They fought, and Zayd ibn Harithah was killed. Ja'far ibn Abi Talib took the banner, and fought until his right hand was severed. He took the banner with his left hand, and it was severed. He then embraced it and was killed in that manner. Abdullah ibn Rawahah took the banner and hesitated for a moment before dismounting, then he resolved and fought until he was killed. Thabit ibn Aqram took the banner and said, "O Muslims, agree upon one of your own." They said, "You." He said, "No." The people agreed upon Khalid ibn al-Walid. When he took the banner, he defended the people and rallied them. Then he retreated, and they retreated with him, until he withdrew with the Muslims who were with him. Khalid ibn al-Walid said, "On the day of Mu'tah, nine swords broke in my hand, and nothing remained in my hand but a Yemeni blade." This implies that they inflicted heavy casualties upon the enemy, for otherwise, they would not have been able to extricate themselves. For this reason and others, some scholars have concluded that the Muslims were victorious in this battle and were not defeated. Anas, may God be pleased with him, reported that the Prophet, peace be upon him, informed the people of the deaths of Zayd, Ja'far, and Ibn Rawahah before their news reached them. He said, "Zayd took the banner and was struck down. Then Ja'far took it and was struck down. Then Ibn Rawahah took it and was struck down, and his eyes were shedding tears, until a sword from the swords of God took it, and God granted them victory."

title: The Battle of Dhat al-Salasil.
details:
This occurred after the Battle of Mu'tah, and it was named Dhat al-Salasil because it took place near a water source called al-Salasil. The Prophet, peace be upon him, received news that a gathering of the Quda'ah tribe had assembled and intended to approach the outskirts of Medina. The Prophet, peace be upon him, summoned Amr ibn al-'As, gave him a white banner, and dispatched him with three hundred of the prominent Emigrants and Helpers. Amr ibn al-'As, may Allah be pleased with him, was their commander. Amr said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent for me and said: "Take your clothes and your weapons, then come to me." I came to him while he was performing ablution. He looked up at me, then lowered his head, and said: "I intend to send you on a mission, and Allah will grant you safety and spoils, and I desire for you a good amount of wealth." I said: "O Messenger of Allah, I did not embrace Islam for the sake of wealth, but rather I embraced Islam out of a desire for Islam and to be with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him." He said: "O Amr, good wealth is indeed good for a good man."

During the expedition, his companions asked him to light a fire, but he forbade them. They spoke to Abu Bakr, who then spoke to him about it. He said: "No one among them shall light a fire unless I throw him into it." He said: "They encountered the enemy and defeated them. They wanted to pursue them, but he forbade them. When that army returned, they mentioned this to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and complained to him. He said: 'O Messenger of Allah, I disliked allowing them to light a fire lest their enemy see their small numbers, and I disliked them pursuing lest they receive reinforcements and turn back upon them.' So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, praised his decision..."

In this expedition, Amr led the people in prayer while he was in a state of ritual impurity (junub) and had water. He did not do more than wash his private parts and perform tayammum. When Amr returned to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he asked him about his prayer. Amr informed him, saying: "By Him Who sent you with the truth, if I had performed a full bath, I would have died. I have never felt cold like that before. And Allah, the Almighty, said: {And do not kill yourselves. Indeed, Allah is to you ever Merciful.} [An-Nisa: 29]." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, smiled and said nothing to him.

title: The expedition of Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah, may Allah be pleased with him, to the coast of the Red Sea.
details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Abu Ubaidah ibn al-Jarrah with three hundred men to the coast of the sea. The purpose of this expedition was to scout a caravan of Quraysh and to fight a tribe from Juhaynah. He provided them with a waterskin of dates, which Abu Ubaidah rationed out to them, to the point where he had to count them, giving each man one date per day. One day, when he distributed them, a date was missing for one man, and he noticed its absence that day. When their provisions ran out, they ate khabat, which is the leaves of the salim tree. The army was therefore named the "Army of Khabat." They suffered severe hunger. Qais ibn Sa'd ibn Ubadah, who was one of the soldiers in this expedition, slaughtered three young camels, then three more, and then three more. Abu Ubaidah then forbade him. The sea then cast forth an animal for them, called the 'anbar. They ate from it for twenty nights and used its fat for anointing, until their bodies recovered and improved. Abu Ubaidah took one of its ribs and measured it against the tallest man in the army and the tallest camel, and the camel was ridden under it. They also took provisions of its meat, dried in strips. When they returned to Medina, they came to the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and told him about it. He said, "It is a provision that God brought forth for you. Do you have any of its meat with you to feed us?" They sent some of it to the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, and he ate it.

title: The expedition of Abu Qatadah al-Ansari to Khadrah.
details: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Abu Qatadah ibn Rib'i, may Allah be pleased with him, on a raid to Khadrah. This was because the Banu Ghaftan were gathering in Khadrah, which is the land of Muharib in Najd. So, he sent him, peace and blessings be upon him, with fifteen men. They killed some of them, took captives, and acquired spoils. His absence lasted fifteen nights.

title: The expedition of Abu Qatadah, may Allah be pleased with him, to the valley of Idham.
details: When Quraysh and those with them broke the treaty between them and the Muslims at Hudaybiyyah, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, resolved to march against them. He ordered the people to prepare and informed them that he was heading to Mecca, saying: "O Allah, blind Quraysh to our movements and intelligence, so that we may surprise them in their land." To further conceal and obscure his intentions, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent a detachment of eight men, under the command of Abu Qatadah ibn al-Ribi', to Batn Idham, between Dhi Khashab and Dhi al-Marwah, three days' journey from Medina, at the beginning of this noble month. This was so that anyone who thought might assume that the Prophet, peace be upon him, was heading in that direction, and that news would spread accordingly. This detachment continued its journey until, upon reaching their assigned location, they learned that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, had already departed for Mecca. They then proceeded to join him.

title: The Conquest of Mecca
details:
The reason for this was that the polytheists broke the treaty between them and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. They raided one of the tribes allied with the Messenger, peace be upon him, which was the tribe of Khuza'ah. When the Prophet, peace be upon him, learned of the matter, he ordered the people to prepare without informing them of his destination. Then he proceeded until he encamped at Marr al-Dhahrān, a valley near Mecca.

It is narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, set out from Medina in Ramadan with ten thousand men. This was eight and a half years after his arrival in Medina. He and the Muslims with him marched to Mecca, fasting and being fasted. When they reached al-Kadīd, a water source between 'Usfan and Qudayd, he broke his fast, and they broke theirs.

Abu Sufyan had seen the army of the Prophet, peace be upon him, before their entry into Mecca, and was terrified by what he saw. He then embraced Islam. After that, he went to his people and cried out to them, warning them that they had no strength against the army of Muhammad, peace be upon him. He told them what the Prophet, peace be upon him, had said: "Whoever enters the house of Abu Sufyan is safe, and whoever locks his door is safe, and whoever enters the Masjid is safe." So the people dispersed to their homes and to the Masjid.

It is narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, that the Prophet, peace be upon him, entered Mecca in the year of the Conquest from Kada', which is in the upper part of Mecca. On the day of the Conquest, the Prophet, peace be upon him, declared the blood of some of the polytheists forfeit. He found around the Kaaba three hundred and sixty idols, and he began to strike them with a stick in his hand, saying: "Truth has come, and falsehood has vanished. Truth has come, and falsehood can neither originate nor restore."

The narrations differ regarding the duration of his stay, peace be upon him, in the year of the Conquest. The most probable view, and Allah knows best, is that it was nineteen days.

title: The expedition of Khalid ibn al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him, to al-Uzza in Nakhla.
details: When the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, felt secure after the Conquest, he sent Khalid ibn al-Walid to al-Uzza, five nights remaining in this noble month, to demolish it. It was in Nakhla, and it belonged to Quraysh and all of Banu Kinana, and it was their greatest idol. Its custodians were Banu Shayban. Khalid set out to it with thirty horsemen until he reached it and demolished it. When he returned, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, asked him, "Did you see anything?" He said, "No." He said, "Then you did not demolish it. Return to it and demolish it." Khalid returned, enraged, having drawn his sword. A naked, black woman with disheveled hair came out to him. The custodian began to shout at her, and Khalid struck her, cleaving her in two. Then he returned to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, and informed him. He said, "Yes, that was al-Uzza, and she despaired of ever being worshipped in your lands."

title: The expedition of Amr ibn al-As, may Allah be pleased with him, to Suwa', the idol of Hudhayl.
details: The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, sent Amr ibn al-As to Suwa' to demolish it. Suwa' was an idol of the people of Noah, peace be upon him. It later belonged to the Banu Hudhayl, a branch of the Mudhar tribe. This idol remained erected, worshipped and venerated by Hudhayl. They even used to make pilgrimage to it until Mecca was conquered and Hudhayl entered the religion of God in multitudes. Its location was in Ruhat, approximately 150 kilometers northeast of Mecca. When Amr arrived, its custodian asked him, "What do you want?" Amr replied, "The Messenger of God, peace be upon him, has commanded me to demolish it." The custodian said, "You cannot do that." Amr asked, "Why?" He replied, "You will be prevented." Amr said, "Are you still on falsehood even now? Woe to you! Does it hear or see?" Then he approached and broke it. He ordered his companions, and they demolished its treasury house, but found nothing in it. Then he said to the custodian, "What did you see?" He replied, "I have submitted to God."

title: The expedition of Khalid ibn al-Walid, may Allah be pleased with him, to Banu Judhaymah.
details: When Khalid ibn al-Walid returned from destroying al-Uzza, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent him to Banu Judhaymah, inviting them to Islam, not to fight them. He set out with three hundred and fifty men from the Muhajirun, the Ansar, and Banu Sulaym. When he reached them, he invited them to Islam, but they did not respond well, saying, "We have embraced Islam," and instead kept saying, "We have apostatized, we have apostatized." Khalid took this as mockery of Islam, as the Quraysh used to say "apostate" to taunt those who embraced Islam. So Khalid began to kill them and take them captive. He handed over a captive to each man who was with him, and one day he ordered each man to kill his captive. Ibn Umar and his companions refused until they came to the Prophet, peace be upon him, and told him about it. The Prophet, peace be upon him, raised his hands and said twice: "O Allah, I declare myself innocent of what Khalid has done." Banu Sulaym were the ones who killed their captives, not the Muhajirun and the Ansar. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Ali, who paid the blood money for their slain and compensated for what was lost.

title: The Battle of Ta'if after the Muslims besieged it for forty nights.
details: After the Muslims pursued the remnants of the fleeing Hawazin in Awṭas and Nakhla, they turned to eliminate Thaqif, who had fled from Hunayn and Awṭas and fortified themselves in their impregnable fortresses in Ta'if. In the Sahih of Muslim, it is narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and the Muslims with him besieged the polytheists in Ta'if for forty nights. From Abu Najih al-Sulami, he said: "We besieged the fortress of Ta'if with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: 'Whoever hits with an arrow, he shall have a rank in Paradise.' He said: 'On that day, I hit sixteen arrows...'" And twenty-three men fled from that fortress to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. From Abdullah bin Umar, he said: "When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, besieged Ta'if and did not achieve anything from them, he said: 'We are returning, God willing.' This weighed heavily on them, and they said: 'We are leaving without conquering it.' So he said: 'Go forth to battle.' They went forth and sustained injuries. Then he said: 'We are returning tomorrow, God willing.' This pleased them, and the Prophet, peace be upon him, smiled."

title: The Battle of Hunayn (Hawazin).
details: Hunayn: A valley next to Dhi al-Majaz, near Ta'if. It is a dozen miles from Mecca, in the direction of al-Sharai' and the Great Flood. It is said that it was named Hunayn after a man called Hunayn ibn Qabithah ibn Mahla'il. The Prophet, peace be upon him, had stayed in Mecca for 19 days until Hawazin and Thaqif came and camped in Hunayn, intending to fight the Prophet, peace be upon him. They had gathered before that when they heard of the departure of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, from Medina, thinking that he was coming for them. When they learned that he had arrived in Mecca, they began to prepare to confront him. They intended it to be a decisive battle, so they mobilized their wealth, women, and children so that none of them would flee and abandon their families and property. Their leader was Malik ibn 'Awf al-Nadri, and they mobilized Ghatafan and others with them. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, prepared to confront them. He borrowed thirty camels and thirty shields from Ya'la ibn Umayyah, and borrowed one hundred shields from Safwan ibn Umayyah. He appointed 'Attab ibn Asid ibn Abi al-'As as governor of Mecca. It is confirmed in the two Sahih collections that the freed slaves (al-tulaqa') went out with him to Hunayn. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, met the enemy with his army in the valley of Hunayn in the early morning. They descended into it, and upon entering the valley, they attacked Hawazin, who were routed. The Muslims then fell upon the spoils they had left behind. While they were in this state, Hawazin confronted them and rained down a volley of arrows upon them. The Muslims had not expected this, and the earth became straitened for them. They turned and fled, not looking back. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, turned to the right, saying: "Where are the people? Come to me! I am the Messenger of Allah! I am the Messenger of Allah! I am Muhammad ibn Abdullah." The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, ordered his uncle Al-Abbas – who had a loud voice – to call out to the people to stand firm, specifically mentioning the companions of the Pledge of Ridwan. They rushed to him, then he called out to the Ansar, then to the Banu al-Harith ibn al-Khazraj, and they flew to him, saying: "Labbayk, Labbayk" (Here we are, here we are). A fierce battle ensued against Hawazin. When the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, saw the battle intensifying, he said: "This is when the furnace has heated up." Then he took some pebbles – or dust – and threw them at the faces of the disbelievers, saying: "May the faces be disfigured." No one among them whom Allah created was spared from having his eyes filled with dust from that handful. They turned and fled, and the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "By the Lord of Muhammad, they are defeated." In another narration: "By the Lord of the Ka'bah, they are defeated! By the Lord of the Ka'bah, they are defeated!" It has been narrated that the killed from Banu Malik of Thaqif alone reached 70. At Awstas, 300 from Banu Malik were killed, and a large number from Banu Nasr ibn Mu'awiyah, then from Banu Ri'ab, were killed. It has been narrated that the captives of Hunayn, women and children, numbered 6,000. Meanwhile, four Muslims were killed.

title: The Umrah of Ji'ranah.
details: It is established that the Prophet, peace be upon him, performed `Umrah from Al-Ji`ranah in the year of Hunayn. This `Umrah is the third after the `Umrah of Al-Hudaybiyah and the `Umrah of Al-Qada'. Ibn Hajar said: The Prophet, peace be upon him, entered the state of Ihram from Al-Ji`ranah and entered Mecca at night, then he completed the rites of `Umrah, and then returned at night and woke up in Al-Ji`ranah as if he had stayed overnight. Ibrahim Al-Nakha`i said: They used to prefer entering Mecca during the day and leaving it at night. And from `Ata': If you wish, enter at night, for you are not like the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He was a leader, and he wanted to enter it during the day so that people could see him. End. The implication of this is that for one who is a leader to be followed, it is recommended for him to enter during the day.

title: The death of Umm Kulthum, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.
details: She is Umm Kulthum, daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him – the fourth noble daughter of the Prophet. Her mother was Khadijah bint Khuwaylid, may Allah be pleased with her. It is said that she was married to Utaybah ibn Abi Lahab, then he separated from her. She embraced Islam and migrated after the Prophet, peace be upon him. When her sister Ruqayyah passed away, Uthman married her in Rabi' al-Awwal in the third year (of Hijra), but she did not bear him any children.

title: The Year of Delegations.
details: Among the most prominent results of the Conquest of Mecca was that the Arab tribes and their individuals began to hasten their embrace of Islam. This was because they had been awaiting the outcome of the conflict between the Muslims and Quraysh. Amr ibn Salamah narrated, saying: "We used to be at a watering place where people passed by, and travelers would pass us. We would ask them, 'What is happening with the people? What is happening with the people? Who is this man?' They would say, 'He claims that Allah sent him, and revealed to him – or: Allah revealed such and such.' I would memorize those words, as if they were imprinted in my chest. The Arabs used to delay their Islam until the Conquest, saying, 'Leave him and his people. If he prevails over them, then he is a true prophet.' So, when the Conquest of Mecca occurred, every tribe hastened to embrace Islam, and my father hastened my people to embrace Islam."

title: The obligation of Hajj was revealed.
details: Pilgrimage was known before the prophethood. Abraham called people to pilgrimage, and Moses and other prophets performed it. Pilgrimage remained known, but the polytheists altered it as they pleased. The first to make alterations was Amr ibn Luhayy. Then, Allah the Almighty ordained pilgrimage upon Muslims who are able to undertake the journey, saying: {And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House, for whoever is able to find thereto a way} [Al-Imran: 97]. The Messenger, peace be upon him, explained its rites in full during the Farewell Pilgrimage in the year 10 AH. There is disagreement regarding the year pilgrimage was ordained; it is said to have been ordained in the year six, or in the year seven, or in the year eight, or other opinions exist.

title: The death of the Negus, the ruler of Abyssinia, may Allah be pleased with him.
details: He is Ashama ibn Abjar, the King of Abyssinia. "Najashi" is a title for him and the kings of Abyssinia. The meaning of "Ashama" is "gift," and it is also said to mean "gift of God" or "generosity." He assumed rule after the death of his uncle. Years after his reign and the spread of his justice, he embraced Islam during the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him. He treated the Muslims who migrated to his land with kindness. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to his companions about the Najashi: "If you were to go to the land of Abyssinia, there is a king there under whom no one is wronged. It is a land of truth, until Allah grants you a way out." When he died, the Prophet, peace be upon him, led the funeral prayer in absentia for him in Medina. Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, reported that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, informed them of the death of the Najashi, the ruler of Abyssinia, on the day he died, and said: "Ask forgiveness for your brother." Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, reported that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said when the Najashi died: "A righteous man died today. So, stand up and offer the funeral prayer for your brother Ashama."

title: The Battle of Tabuk and the Army of Hardship.
details:
Tabuk is a place between Wadi al-Qura and Sham. Abu Musa al-Ash'ari, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "My companions sent me to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, to ask him for mounts for them, as they were with him in the Army of Hardship, which was the expedition to Tabuk..."

The hadith of Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, indicates the severe hardship the Companions faced in terms of wealth, provisions, and mounts. As narrated by Muslim, also from Abu Hurayrah, may Allah be pleased with him, the Muslims suffered from a lack of provisions on the way to this expedition, to the extent that they sucked the date pits and drank water with them. In another narration by Muslim, they asked the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, for permission to slaughter their mounts to eat. And Allah Almighty said: {Allah has turned in forgiveness to the Prophet and to the Emigrants and Helpers who followed him in the hour of hardship, after the hearts of a party of them had falved. Then He turned to them in forgiveness. Indeed, He is to them Kind and Merciful.} [Quran 9:117].

Ibn Kathir said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, resolved to fight the Romans because they were the closest people to him and the most deserving of being invited to the truth due to their proximity to Islam and its people. And Allah Almighty said: {O you who have believed, fight those adjacent to you of the disbelievers and let them find harshness in you, and know that Allah is with the righteous.} [Quran 9:123].

The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, clarified the objective of this expedition. From Mu'adh, may Allah be pleased with him, it is narrated that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "You will arrive tomorrow, Allah willing, at the spring of Tabuk. You will not reach it until the day has brightened. So whoever among you arrives there, let him not touch any of its water until I come."

The well-known and preferred opinion is that the army of Tabuk numbered thirty thousand. However, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, did not encounter any fighting from the enemy. He returned to Medina victorious after staying in Tabuk for twenty nights.

title: The death of the head of the hypocrites, Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul.
details: He is Abdullah ibn Ubayy ibn Salul, the head of the hypocrites. He fell ill in the remaining nights of Shawwal after the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned from the Battle of Tabuk. When he died, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sought forgiveness for him and prayed over him after Umar attempted to prevent him from praying over him. The Quran was revealed thereafter, agreeing with Umar, may Allah be pleased with him. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, only prayed over him to uphold the outward ruling, which was Islam, and for the religious benefit of reconciling the hearts of his people and followers. A large group of hypocrites pledged allegiance to him, so perhaps they would be influenced, turn away from their hypocrisy, take heed, and become sincere to Allah and His Messenger.

title: The Pilgrimage of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq and the Revelation of Surat Bara'ah.
details: The Prophet, peace be upon him, sent Abu Bakr as the commander of the Hajj after the end of Dhu al-Qi'dah to perform the Hajj for the Muslims. The polytheists were still performing their Hajj in their usual way. Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, and the Muslims with him set out. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, also sent Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, after Abu Bakr al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, to be with him. Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, was to personally deliver the declaration of disassociation to the polytheists on behalf of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, as he was his cousin and from his kin. Abu Hurayrah said: Abu Bakr sent me on that Hajj with some callers to prayer on the Day of Sacrifice, announcing in Mina: "No polytheist shall perform Hajj after this year, and no one shall circumambulate the House naked." Humayd ibn 'Abd al-Rahman said: Then the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent Ali after him and ordered him to announce the declaration of disassociation. Abu Hurayrah said: Ali announced with us among the people of Mina on the Day of Sacrifice: "No polytheist shall perform Hajj after this year, and no one shall circumambulate the House naked."

title: The succession of delegations to the Prophet, peace be upon him.
details: The delegations continued to arrive to the Messenger of God, peace be upon him. Among them was the delegation of the Christians of Najran, and he made peace with them, stipulating the jizya (poll tax) and granting them protection.

title: The death of Ibrahim, son of the Prophet, peace be upon him.
details: Ibrahim was the son of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and his mother was Maria al-Qibtiyya. All of the Prophet's children, peace be upon him, were from Khadijah, may Allah be pleased with her, except for Ibrahim, who was from Maria al-Qibtiyya the Egyptian, may Allah be pleased with her. Anas ibn Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I have not seen anyone more compassionate to children than the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He said: Ibrahim was being nursed in the high lands of Medina. The Prophet, peace be upon him, would go with us, and we would enter the house, and it would be smoky. His wet nurse was a blacksmith. He would take him, kiss him, and then return." Amr said: When Ibrahim died, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, Ibrahim is my son, and he died while still nursing. He has two wet nurses who will complete his nursing in Paradise." Al-Mughira ibn Shu'bah said: The sun was eclipsed during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on the day Ibrahim died. The people said: The sun was eclipsed because of Ibrahim's death. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "The sun and the moon do not eclipse for the death of anyone, nor for their life. When you see that, then pray and supplicate to Allah." Abu Bakra said: The sun was eclipsed during the time of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. He went out, dragging his cloak, until he reached the mosque. The people gathered around him. He led them in two rak'ahs, and the sun became clear. He said: "The sun and the moon are two signs from the signs of Allah, and they do not eclipse for the death of anyone. When that happens, then pray and supplicate until what is with you is revealed." This was because a son of the Prophet, peace be upon him, died, and he was called Ibrahim. The people spoke about this. Ibrahim was born to him in Medina from his concubine Maria al-Qibtiyya in the year eight of the Hijra. His freedman Abu Rafi' gave him the good news, so he gave him a slave. He died as an infant before weaning, and there is a difference of opinion as to whether he prayed over him or not, with two opinions.

title: The Farewell Pilgrimage, also known as the Pilgrimage of Islam or the Pilgrimage of Conveyance.
details: It was named the Farewell Pilgrimage because the Prophet, peace be upon him, bid farewell to the people during it, and he did not perform Hajj after it. It was also named the Pilgrimage of Islam because the Prophet, peace be upon him, did not perform Hajj from Medina except for this one. It was also named the Pilgrimage of Conveyance because the Prophet, peace be upon him, conveyed to the people the law of Allah in Hajj, both in word and deed. There was nothing left of the pillars and foundations of Islam that the Prophet, peace be upon him, had not clarified. When he clarified, elucidated, and explained the Sharia of Hajj to them, Allah, the Exalted, revealed to him while he was standing at Arafat: "{This day I have perfected for you your religion and completed My favor upon you and have approved for you Islam as religion}" [Al-Ma'idah: 3]. When the Messenger, peace be upon him, announced his intention to perform Hajj in that year, a large number of people came to Medina, all seeking to follow the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and perform Hajj like him. He set out from Medina five nights before the end of Dhu al-Qi'dah. Many events occurred for the Prophet, peace be upon him, during this journey and his return.

title: The greatest calamity for the Muslims was the death of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him.
details: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, fell ill after his return from the Farewell Pilgrimage, until his pain intensified while he was in the house of Maymunah, may God be pleased with her. He called his wives and asked their permission to be nursed in the house of Aisha, may God be pleased with her. Aisha, may God be pleased with her, said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to say during his illness in which he died: "O Aisha, I still feel the pain of the food I ate in Khaybar, and now is the time when I feel my aorta breaking from that poison." His illness lasted for ten days. Ibn Hajar said: (There is a difference of opinion regarding the duration of his illness. The majority hold that it was thirteen days, and it was said that it was one day more, and it was said that it was one day less, and it was said: ten days. Sulayman al-Taymi was certain of this in his accounts of battles, and al-Bayhaqi narrated it with a sound chain of transmission). Then God Almighty took him on Monday, the twelfth of Rabi' al-Awwal, and he was 63 years old. He was shrouded, peace and blessings be upon him, in three white Sahuliyyah garments made of cotton, which did not include a shirt or a turban. The people prayed over him in groups, and he was buried in the place of his death in the chamber of Aisha, may God be pleased with her. May God Almighty reward him on behalf of the Muslims with the best reward He has ever given a prophet for his people.

title: The revolt of Al-Aswad Al-Ansi in Yemen and his killing at the hands of Firuz al-Daylami.
details: Al-Aswad al-Ansi – whose name was Abhalah ibn Ka'b ibn Gawth – emerged in the final days of the life of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, with seven hundred fighters. He wrote to the agents of the Prophet, peace be upon him, saying: "O rebels against us, return to us what you have taken from our land, and keep what you have gathered, for we are more deserving of it, and you remain as you are." Then he proceeded with his fighters to Najran and captured it. Afterward, he intended for Sana'a. Shahar ibn Bazham came out to him, and they fought. Al-Aswad defeated and killed him, and married Shahar ibn Bazham's wife, who was the daughter of Fayruz al-Daylami's cousin. Her name was Azadh, and she was a believer in Allah and His Messenger, peace be upon him, and among the righteous. Al-Ansi occupied Sana'a. Mu'adh ibn Jabal and Abu Musa al-Ash'ari went to Hadhramaut, and the agents of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, retreated to Al-Tahir. Umar ibn Haram and Khalid ibn Sa'id ibn al-'As returned to Medina. Yemen became secured for Al-Aswad al-Ansi, and his affair began to spread like wildfire. His rule intensified, and his situation grew grave. A group of the people of Yemen apostatized. The Muslims there dealt with him with dissimulation. When the news of Al-Aswad al-Ansi reached him, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, sent his letter with Qays ibn Makshuh, ordering the Muslims there to fight and confront Al-Ansi. Mu'adh ibn Jabal took charge of this letter perfectly. Mu'adh ibn Jabal and those who rallied around him from the people of Yemen, and Qays ibn Abd Yaghuth, the commander of Al-Aswad's army, and Fayruz al-Daylami, agreed to assassinate Al-Aswad and kill him. They pledged to do so. When night fell, they entered his house. Fayruz al-Daylami approached him. Al-Aswad was sleeping on a silk mattress, his head sunk into his body, snoring heavily, with the woman sitting beside him. Fayruz attacked him and grappled with him, who was like a camel. He seized his head, crushed his neck, and placed his knees on his back until he killed him. Qays, Dadhuwayh, and Fayruz sat planning how to inform their followers. They agreed that in the morning, they would call out their rallying cry, which was between them and the Muslims. When morning came, one of them – Qays – stood on the rampart of the fortress and called out their rallying cry. The Muslims and the disbelievers gathered around the fortress. Qays then cried out: "I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah, and that Abhalah is a liar!" He threw his head down to them. His followers fled, and people pursued them, capturing and ambushing them on every road, taking them prisoner. Islam and its adherents prevailed. The deputies of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, returned to their posts. They agreed that Mu'adh ibn Jabal would lead the people in prayer. They wrote the news to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. The duration of his rule, from his emergence until his death, was three or four months.

title: Naissance du Prophète Muhammad ibn Abdullah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui.
details: Les historiens et biographes divergent sur le jour et le mois de sa naissance, que la paix soit sur lui. Ils s'accordent cependant sur le fait que sa naissance, que la paix soit sur lui, eut lieu un lundi de l'année de l'Éléphant. Ibn al-Qayyim a dit : "Il n'y a pas de divergence sur le fait qu'il est né, que la paix soit sur lui, dans la partie intérieure de La Mecque, et que sa naissance eut lieu l'année de l'Éléphant". D'après Ibn Abbas, que Dieu soit satisfait d'eux, il a dit : (Le Messager de Dieu, que la paix soit sur lui, est né l'année de l'Éléphant), et c'est ce dont aucun savant ne doute. Khalifa ibn Khayyat, Ibn al-Jazar, Ibn Dihya et Ibn al-Jawzi ont rapporté un consensus à ce sujet. Quant à sa naissance un lundi, d'après Abu Qatada al-Ansari, que Dieu soit satisfait de lui, il a dit : "On interrogea le Prophète, que la paix soit sur lui, sur le jeûne du lundi. Il dit : "C'est un jour où je suis né, et un jour où j'ai été envoyé ou où la révélation m'a été descendue". Ibn Kathir a dit : "Celui qui dit qu'il est né le vendredi 17 Rabi' al-Awwal est loin de la vérité, voire erroné". Le point de divergence concernait la détermination du mois et du jour de celui-ci. Ibn Ishaq a rapporté d'un groupe de compagnons du Messager de Dieu, que la paix soit sur lui, qu'ils lui dirent : "Ô Messager de Dieu, parle-nous de toi". Il dit : (Oui, je suis la prière de mon père Abraham, la bonne nouvelle de Jésus, et ma mère a vu, lorsqu'elle m'a porté, qu'une lumière est sortie d'elle et a illuminé pour elle les palais de la Syrie). Sa naissance, que la paix soit sur lui, eut lieu après le décès de son père Abdullah, car il était encore dans le ventre de sa mère lorsque son père mourut, et le Prophète, que la paix soit sur lui, grandit donc orphelin. Sa naissance eut lieu dans la maison d'Abu Talib, dans le quartier des Banu Hashim.
location_name: La maison d'Abou Talib dans le quartier des Banu Hashim

title: Le premier incident de la fente de la poitrine du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui.
details: D'après Anas ibn Malik : Le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, vint à lui Gabriel, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, alors qu'il jouait avec des enfants. Il le saisit et le jeta à terre, puis lui ouvrit la poitrine. Il en sortit le cœur, puis en retira une masse de sang caillé. Il dit : « Ceci est la part de Satan en toi. » Puis il le lava dans une cuve d'or avec de l'eau de Zamzam, puis il le referma, puis le remit à sa place. Les enfants vinrent en courant vers sa mère – c'est-à-dire sa nourrice – et dirent : « Muhammad a été tué ! » Ils le rencontrèrent alors qu'il avait le teint pâle. Anas dit : « J'ai vu la trace de cette couture sur sa poitrine. »

title: Décès d'Amina bint Wahb, mère du Prophète, et la tutelle d'Umm Ayman sur lui, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui.
details: Lorsque le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, eut atteint l'âge de six ans, sa mère, la noble Amina bint Wahb, sortit avec lui pour visiter ses oncles maternels, les Banu Adi ibn al-Najjar, en leur compagnie. Il y avait aussi sa nourrice, Umm Ayman, qu'Allah soit satisfaite d'elle, et ils voyageaient sur deux chameaux. Sa mère s'installa avec lui dans la demeure d'Al-Nabigha, près de la tombe de son père, Abd Allah ibn Abd al-Muttalib. Elle resta avec ses oncles maternels pendant un mois, puis sa mère le ramena à La Mecque. Alors qu'ils étaient à Al-Abwa, sa mère Amina bint Wahb mourut. Umm Ayman, qu'Allah soit satisfaite d'elle, le ramena. Son nom était Baraka bint Tha'laba ibn Hisn. Umm Ayman, qu'Allah soit satisfaite d'elle, aimait le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, d'un amour intense et prenait grand soin de lui, le protégeant par sa sollicitude et sa tendresse. Le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, la traitait avec respect et bienveillance. Lorsqu'il fut plus âgé, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, il l'affranchit, puis il la maria à Zayd ibn Haritha, qu'Allah soit satisfait de lui, dont elle eut Usama ibn Zayd, qu'Allah soit satisfait d'eux. Umm Ayman, qu'Allah soit satisfaite d'elle, mourut cinq mois après la mort du Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui.

title: La prise en charge du Messager d'Allah par Abd al-Muttalib et sa connaissance de son statut.
details: Lorsque Amina, la mère du Messager, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, mourut alors qu'il avait six ans, sa tutelle revint à son grand-père Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hachim. Abd al-Muttalib était un homme d'honneur et de mérite parmi son peuple, et Quraysh le surnommait "Al-Fadl" (le méritant) en raison de sa générosité et de sa noblesse. Il avait pris en charge les fonctions de Rifaada (fourniture de nourriture aux pèlerins) et de Siqaaya (fourniture d'eau aux pèlerins) après la mort de son père Hachim ibn Abd Manaf. Abd al-Muttalib aimait son petit-fils Muhammad d'un amour immense, le préférant à tous ses autres fils et éprouvant pour lui plus de tendresse qu'il n'en éprouvait pour ses propres enfants. Ibn Ishaq, que Dieu ait pitié de lui, a dit : "Le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, était avec son grand-père Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hachim - c'est-à-dire après la mort de sa mère Amina bint Wahb. Un lit était installé pour Abd al-Muttalib à l'ombre de la Kaaba, et ses fils s'asseyaient autour de ce lit jusqu'à ce qu'il s'y installe, aucun de ses fils n'osant s'y asseoir en signe de respect pour lui. Le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, venait alors, étant un jeune garçon fort et plein de vie, et s'asseyait dessus. Ses oncles le prenaient pour le faire reculer, mais Abd al-Muttalib, lorsqu'il voyait cela, disait : 'Laissez mon fils. Par Dieu, il aura une grande destinée.' Puis il le faisait asseoir avec lui sur son lit, lui caressait le dos de sa main, et était heureux de ce qu'il voyait faire." Abd al-Muttalib ne mangeait pas un repas sans dire : "Apportez-moi mon fils !" et on le lui apportait. Lorsque la mort approcha Abd al-Muttalib, il recommanda à Abu Talib de veiller sur le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, et de le protéger.

title: Mort d'Abd al-Muttalib et son testament à Abu Talib concernant le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui.
details:
Lorsque le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, atteignit l'âge de huit ans, son grand-père Abd al-Muttalib mourut. Abd al-Muttalib, à l'approche de sa mort, avait recommandé à son fils Abu Talib de veiller sur le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, de le protéger et de prendre soin de lui. Il le confia à Abu Talib car Abd Allah, le père du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, et Abu Talib étaient issus de la même mère. Ainsi, après la mort d'Abd al-Muttalib, ce fut Abu Talib qui prit en charge les affaires du Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, après son grand-père.

Ibn Sa'd et Ibn Asakir rapportèrent, d'après Ibn Abbas, que Dieu soit satisfait d'eux, et d'autres, qu'ils dirent : Lorsque Abd al-Muttalib mourut, Abu Talib prit le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, et il restait avec lui. Abu Talib l'aimait d'un amour intense, plus que ses propres enfants. Il ne dormait que près de lui et le privilégiait en matière de nourriture. Les enfants d'Abu Talib, qu'ils mangent tous ensemble ou séparément, ne se rassasiaient pas. Mais si le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, mangeait avec eux, ils se rassasiaient.

Abu Talib, lorsqu'il voulait leur servir le déjeuner ou le dîner, disait : "Attendez jusqu'à ce que mon fils arrive." Le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, venait alors et mangeait avec eux, et ils avaient encore des restes de leur nourriture. S'il n'était pas avec eux, ils ne se rassasiaient pas. S'il s'agissait de lait, il était le premier à en boire, puis les enfants prenaient le qab' (un grand récipient semblable à une jatte) et buvaient dedans jusqu'au dernier, se désaltérant tous d'un seul qab'. L'un d'eux pouvait même boire un qab' à lui seul. Abu Talib disait alors : "Tu es vraiment béni !"

title: Le voyage du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, avec son oncle Abu Talib en Syrie.
details:
Lorsque le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, eut douze ans, son oncle Abu Talib partit en Syrie avec une caravane pour le commerce, et il l'emmena avec lui. Lorsque la caravane s'arrêta à Busra, ils passèrent devant un moine nommé Bahira, qui était versé dans l'Évangile et expert en christianisme. C'est là que Bahira aperçut le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, et il se mit à l'observer et à lui parler. Puis il se tourna vers Abu Talib et lui demanda : "Qui est ce jeune garçon pour toi ?" Il répondit : "Mon fils" (Abu Talib l'appelait son fils, par amour et affection profonds pour lui). Bahira lui dit : "Ce n'est pas ton fils, et le père de ce jeune garçon ne devrait pas être vivant." Il dit : "C'est mon neveu." Il demanda : "Et qu'est-il advenu de son père ?" Il dit : "Il est mort alors que sa mère était enceinte de lui." Bahira dit : "Tu dis la vérité. Rentre avec lui dans son pays et prends garde aux Juifs ; car par Allah, s'ils le voient ici, ils lui souhaiteront du mal ; car ton neveu aura une grande destinée." Abu Talib se hâta de retourner à La Mecque avec lui.

Tirmidhi rapporta qu'Abu Talib sortit en Syrie, et le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, sortit avec lui, ainsi que des notables de Quraysh. Lorsqu'ils approchèrent du moine (c'est-à-dire Bahira), ils descendirent et déchargèrent leurs montures. Le moine sortit à leur rencontre ; auparavant, ils passaient devant lui sans qu'il ne sorte à leur rencontre ni ne leur prête attention. Il dit : Alors qu'ils déchargeaient leurs montures, le moine se faufila parmi eux jusqu'à ce qu'il arrive et prenne la main du Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, et dit : "C'est le maître des mondes, c'est le Messager du Seigneur des mondes, Allah l'enverra comme miséricorde pour les mondes." Certains notables de Quraysh lui dirent : "Comment sais-tu cela ?" Il dit : "Lorsque vous êtes apparus depuis la côte, il n'est pas resté d'arbre ni de pierre qui ne se soit prosterné, et ils ne se prosternent que pour un prophète. Je le reconnais à la marque de la prophétie, sous le cartilage de son épaule, semblable à une pomme." Puis il retourna et leur prépara un repas. Lorsqu'il leur apporta, et que le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, était en train de garder les chameaux, il dit : "Envoyez-le chercher." Le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, arriva, et un nuage l'ombrageait. Lorsqu'il s'approcha du peuple, il trouva qu'ils l'avaient devancé à l'ombre de l'arbre. Lorsque le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, s'assit, l'ombre de l'arbre se pencha sur lui. Bahira dit : "Regardez l'ombre de l'arbre qui s'est penchée sur lui !" Il dit : Et pendant qu'il se tenait devant eux, il les suppliait de ne pas l'emmener à Rome ; car si les Romains le voyaient, ils le reconnaîtraient à sa description et le tueraient. Il se tourna et vit sept hommes arriver de Rome. Il les rencontra et leur demanda : "Qu'est-ce qui vous amène ?" Ils dirent : "Nous sommes venus car ce prophète doit apparaître ce mois-ci. Il n'y a pas une route sur laquelle des gens n'aient été envoyés, et nous avons été informés de sa nouvelle. Nous avons été envoyés sur ta route." Il dit : "Y a-t-il eu des gens envoyés après vous qui soient meilleurs que vous ?" Ils dirent : "Nous n'avons reçu la nouvelle de sa venue que sur ta route." Il dit : "Et si Allah a voulu décréter une chose, quelqu'un peut-il la repousser ?" Ils dirent : "Non." Il dit : "Alors faites-lui allégeance." Et ils restèrent avec lui. Il dit : Le moine Bahira dit : "Je vous adjure par Allah, qui est son gardien ?" Abu Talib dit : Il ne cessa de le supplier jusqu'à ce qu'Abu Talib le ramène.

title: La Guerre de Fijar, et le témoignage du Prophète (que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui) à son sujet.
details: Lorsque le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, eut quatorze ou quinze ans, la guerre de Fujar éclata entre Quraysh et ceux qui étaient avec eux de Kinana, et entre Qays Aylan. Ce fut l'un des plus grands jours des Arabes. Ce qui la déclencha fut que Urwah ar-Rahhal ibn 'Utbah ibn Rabi'ah accorda protection à une caravane de Nu'man ibn al-Mundhir. Al-Barrad ibn Qays, l'un des Banu Damrah ibn Bakr ibn 'Abd Manah ibn Kinana, lui dit : "L'accordes-tu à Kinana ?" Il répondit : "Oui, et à toute la création." Alors Urwah ar-Rahhal partit, et Al-Barrad partit à sa recherche pour le surprendre. Lorsqu'il fut à Tayman Dhi Dhilal, dans la région d'al-'Aliyah, Urwah fut surpris. Al-Barrad se jeta sur lui et le tua durant le mois sacré. C'est pourquoi on l'appela Fujar (la transgression). Un messager vint à Quraysh et dit : "Al-Barrad a tué Urwah alors qu'il était dans le mois sacré à 'Ukaz." Ils partirent, et les Hawazin n'en étaient pas conscients. Puis la nouvelle leur parvint, ils les poursuivirent et les rattrapèrent avant qu'ils n'entrent dans le Haram. Ils se battirent jusqu'à la nuit, puis entrèrent dans le Haram, et les Hawazin cessèrent de les poursuivre. Ils se rencontrèrent à nouveau pendant plusieurs jours, et les gens se soutenaient mutuellement. Chaque tribu de Quraysh et de Kinana avait un chef parmi eux, et chaque tribu de Qays avait un chef parmi eux. Le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, fut témoin de certains de leurs jours, le jour d'al-Nakhlah, et le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, avait alors quatorze ans. On dit vingt ans. Après leur retour de là, en Dhu al-Qi'dah, eut lieu l'alliance des Fudul. La raison en fut qu'un homme de Zabid, originaire du Yémen, vendit une marchandise à al-'As ibn Wa'il as-Sahmi, qui retarda le paiement. L'homme monta sur Abu Qubays et cria, mentionnant son injustice. Alors Quraysh conclut l'alliance des Fudul pour soutenir l'opprimé. Le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, fut témoin de cette alliance avec eux.

title: L'alliance des vertueux entre les tribus de Quraysh.
details: Le Pacte des Vertueux (Hilf al-Fudul) eut lieu durant le mois sacré. Des tribus de Quraysh s'y appelèrent mutuellement : les Banu Hashim, les Banu Muttalib, Asad ibn Abd al-Uzza, Zuhra ibn Kilab et Taym ibn Murra. Ils se réunirent dans la demeure d'Abd Allah ibn Jud'an al-Taymi, en raison de son âge et de son honneur. Ils contractèrent des alliances et des serments de ne trouver à La Mecque aucun opprimé, qu'il soit de ses habitants ou d'autres peuples, sans qu'ils ne se tiennent à ses côtés. Ils seraient contre celui qui l'avait opprimé jusqu'à ce que son tort lui soit réparé. Le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, fut témoin de ce pacte et dit à son sujet : "J'ai assisté dans la demeure d'Abd Allah ibn Jud'an à un pacte pour lequel je n'aurais pas voulu avoir les chamelles rouges. Si l'on m'y appelait dans l'Islam, je répondrais." Cet esprit de ce pacte s'opposait à la fierté et à l'esprit de corps de la Jâhilîyah que l'attachement tribal suscitait. On dit, quant à la cause de ce pacte, qu'un homme de Zubaid arriva à La Mecque avec des marchandises, qu'Al-'As ibn Wa'il al-Sahmi lui acheta, et retint son dû. L'homme fit appel aux alliés : Abd ad-Dar, Makhzum, Jumah, Sahm et Adi, mais ils ne s'en soucièrent guère. Il monta alors sur le mont Abu Qubays et lança des vers décrivant son injustice, élevant sa voix. Zubayr ibn Abd al-Muttalib se rendit alors auprès de lui et dit : "Il n'est pas juste de laisser cela sans suite." Ils se réunirent alors et conclurent le pacte connu sous le nom de Pacte des Vertueux. Puis ils allèrent trouver Al-'As ibn Wa'il et lui arrachèrent le droit du Zubaidi. La raison de sa dénomination est que trois hommes de la tribu de Jurhum, à savoir : Al-Fadl ibn Fadalah, Al-Fadl ibn Wa'dah, et Al-Fadl ibn al-Harith, avaient conclu jadis une alliance similaire. Lorsque l'action des Quraysh ressembla à celle de ces premiers Jurhumites, tous nommés Al-Fadl, le pacte fut appelé Pacte des Vertueux.
location_name: La maison d'Abd Allah ibn Jud'an

title: Le mariage du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, avec Khadija bint Khuwaylid, qu'Allah soit satisfait d'elle.
details: Les avis divergent sur l'âge du Prophète, que la paix et la bénédiction soient sur lui, et sur l'âge de Khadija lors de leur mariage. Il a été dit qu'il avait vingt-cinq ans. D'autres ont dit vingt-sept ans. D'autres encore trente ans. Et d'autres ont avancé d'autres âges. Quant à l'âge de Khadija, les avis ont également divergé, oscillant entre trente-cinq et quarante ans, et d'autres âges. Lorsque Khadija, que Dieu soit satisfait d'elle, entendit parler du Prophète, que la paix et la bénédiction soient sur lui, de son honnêteté et de ses nobles caractères, il est rapporté dans un récit que la sœur de Khadija avait engagé le Messager de Dieu, que la paix et la bénédiction soient sur lui, et son associé pour un voyage. Lorsqu'ils eurent terminé le voyage, il restait une somme due par eux. Son associé commença à venir les réclamer, disant à Muhammad (que la paix et la bénédiction soient sur lui) : "Viens." Il répondait : "Va toi-même, car je suis gêné." Une fois, alors que leur associé était venu, elle dit : "Où est Muhammad ? Pourquoi ne vient-il pas avec toi ?" Il répondit : "Je lui ai dit, mais il prétend être gêné." Elle rapporta cela à sa sœur Khadija, qui dit : "Je n'ai jamais vu un homme plus pudique, ni plus chaste, ni... que Muhammad (que la paix et la bénédiction soient sur lui)." Cela toucha le cœur de sa sœur Khadija, qui l'envoya chercher et lui dit : "Va voir mon père et demande-lui ma main." Il répondit : "Ton père est un homme riche et il ne fera pas cela." Elle dit : "Va le rencontrer et parle-lui, et je m'occuperai du reste." Le Prophète, que la paix et la bénédiction soient sur lui, l'épousa alors qu'elle était déjà mariée et veuve.

title: Le voyage du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, pour la deuxième fois en Syrie.
details: Lorsque le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, atteignit vingt-cinq ans, il n'avait à La Mecque d'autre nom que "Al-Amîn" (le Digne de confiance), en raison des qualités de bien qu'il possédait. Son oncle Abu Talib lui dit : "Ô mon neveu, je suis un homme sans fortune, et le temps est devenu difficile pour nous, et des années difficiles nous ont frappés, et nous n'avons ni ressources ni commerce. Voici la caravane de ton peuple qui s'apprête à sortir pour le Cham, et Khadija bint Khuwailid envoie des hommes de ton peuple dans ses caravanes, pour commercer avec son argent et en tirer des bénéfices. Si tu allais la voir et te proposais à elle, elle se précipiterait vers toi et te préférerait aux autres, en raison de ce qui lui est parvenu de ta pureté. Bien que je déteste que tu ailles au Cham et que je craigne pour toi des Juifs, nous ne pouvons nous en passer." Khadija bint Khuwailid était une femme commerçante, noble et riche, avec un grand commerce qu'elle envoyait au Cham, sa caravane étant comparable à celles de la plupart des Quraysh. Elle louait des hommes et leur confiait de l'argent en partenariat. La réputation de la véracité des paroles du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, de sa grande fiabilité et de la noblesse de son caractère parvint à Khadija. Elle l'envoya donc dans son commerce. Il sortit avec son serviteur Maysara jusqu'à ce qu'ils arrivent au Cham. Ses oncles lui recommandèrent de veiller sur les gens de la caravane jusqu'à leur arrivée au Cham. Ils descendirent sur le marché de Bosra, à l'ombre d'un arbre, près de l'ermitage d'un moine nommé Nestorius. Le moine regarda Maysara, qu'il connaissait, et dit : "Ô Maysara, qui est cet homme qui est descendu sous cet arbre ?" Maysara répondit : "Un homme de Quraysh, originaire du Harem." Le moine lui dit alors : "Personne d'autre que des prophètes ne descend sous cet arbre." Ensuite, le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, vendit sa marchandise, c'est-à-dire son commerce, et acheta ce qu'il voulait acheter. Puis il revint en caravane vers La Mecque avec Maysara. Lorsqu'il arriva à La Mecque avec l'argent de Khadija, elle vendit ce qui était arrivé à un prix double, voire proche. Maysara lui raconta les paroles du moine et ce qu'il avait vu de la situation du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui. Elle se proposa alors à lui, qu'Allah soit satisfait d'elle. Elle était la plus noble des femmes de Quraysh en lignée, la plus grande en honneur et la plus riche en argent. Lorsqu'elle dit cela au Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, il en parla à ses oncles. Son oncle Hamza sortit avec lui et entra chez Khuwailid ibn Asad pour la demander en mariage. Le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, l'épousa. Elle fut la première femme qu'il épousa, et il n'en épousa pas d'autre avant sa mort, qu'Allah soit satisfait d'elle.

title: Le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, place la Pierre Noire à sa place dans la Kaaba.
details: D'après Mujahid, d'après son affranchi, qui lui a rapporté qu'il était parmi ceux qui construisaient la Kaaba à l'époque préislamique... Il a dit : Nous avons construit jusqu'à atteindre l'emplacement de la Pierre Noire, et personne ne voyait la Pierre. Elle était au milieu de nos pierres, comme la tête d'un homme, on pouvait presque y distinguer le visage d'un homme. Alors un clan de Quraysh dit : C'est nous qui la placerons. Et d'autres dirent : C'est nous qui la placerons. Ils dirent alors : Prenez un arbitre entre vous. Ils dirent : Le premier homme qui sortira du défilé. Le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, arriva. Ils dirent : L'Honnête est venu à vous. Ils lui dirent, et il la plaça dans un tissu, puis il appela leurs clans. Ils prirent les coins du tissu avec lui, et il la plaça lui-même, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui.

title: La première descente de la Révélation et la prophétie du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui.
details: La première chose par laquelle la révélation a commencé fut la vision véridique dans le sommeil. Il ne voyait aucune vision sans qu'elle ne se réalise comme l'aube du jour. Puis, le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, aima la solitude. Il s'isolait dans la grotte de Hira et s'y adonnait à l'adoration, jusqu'à ce que Gabriel, que la paix soit sur lui, lui vienne alors qu'il était dans la grotte, avec la parole d'Allah le Très-Haut : {Lis, au nom de ton Seigneur qui a créé, qui a créé l'homme d'une adhérence. Lis ! Ton Seigneur est le plus Généreux, qui a enseigné au moyen du calame, a enseigné à l'homme ce qu'il ne savait pas.} [Al-'Alaq : 1-5]. Il raconta cela à son épouse Khadija, qui raconta ce qui s'était passé à Waraqa ibn Nawfal. Il le crut et dit : "C'est le grand Namus (l'ange de la révélation) qui est venu à Moïse." Puis la révélation s'interrompit pendant un certain temps. Ensuite, Gabriel lui revint alors qu'il était assis sur un siège. Le Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, eut peur de lui et retourna auprès de sa famille en disant : "Enveloppez-moi, enveloppez-moi." Alors Allah le Très-Haut révéla : {Ô toi, le revêtu d'un manteau ! Lève-toi et avertis. Et glorifie ton Seigneur. Et purifie tes vêtements. Et éloigne-toi de l'impiété.} [Al-Muddaththir : 1-5]. Ce fut le début de la prophétie et l'ordre de transmettre le message.

title: La cessation de la révélation pour le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui.
details: La révélation s'est interrompue pour le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui, pendant une période de temps. Cela le peina et l'attrista. Alors vint à lui Gabriel avec la sourate Ad-Duha, pour que son Seigneur lui jure – et c'est Lui qui l'a honoré par ce dont Il l'a honoré – qu'Il ne l'avait pas abandonné. En effet, Al-Bukhari a rapporté dans son Sahih, d'après Jundub ibn Abdullah, que Dieu soit satisfait de lui, qu'il a dit : Gabriel s'est absenté auprès du Prophète, que la paix et les bénédictions soient sur lui. Alors une femme de Quraysh – et c'est Umm Jamil, Arwa bint Harb, sœur d'Abu Sufyan et épouse d'Abu Lahab – dit : Son démon l'a abandonné. Alors descendit : {Par le jour bien éclairé ! Et par la nuit quand elle s'étend ! Ton Seigneur ne t'a abandonné ni ne t'a haï.}

title: Le premier des hommes en foi en Allah et en Son Messager.
details:
La première à croire en Allah et en Son Messager fut Khadija bint Khouwaylid, son épouse, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui. Puis Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, et Ali ibn Abi Talib. Ensuite, Islam fut adopté par Zayd ibn Haritha, l'affranchi du Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui.

Par l'appel d'Abu Bakr As-Siddiq, adoptèrent l'Islam : Othman ibn Affan, Az-Zubayr ibn Al-Awwam, Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, et Talha ibn Ubaydillah, et Abd Ar-Rahman ibn Awf.

Ensuite, adoptèrent l'Islam : Abu Ubaydah ibn Al-Jarrah, Abu Salama ibn Abd Al-Asad, et Othman ibn Maz'un, ainsi que ses deux frères, Qudama et Abd Allah, et son fils, As-Sa'ib ibn Othman ibn Maz'un.

Puis Asma bint Abi Bakr As-Siddiq, et Aïcha bint Abi Bakr As-Siddiq, alors qu'elle était jeune.

Ensuite, adoptèrent l'Islam : Khalid ibn Sa'id ibn Al-As, et avec lui son épouse Amina bint Khallaf ibn As'ad Al-Khuzaiyah. Et Bilal, et Ammar ibn Yasir, et sa mère Sumayya, et Suhayb ibn Sinan An-Namiri, connu sous le nom de Ar-Rumi. Et Amr ibn Absah As-Sulami, et Amr ibn Sa'id ibn Al-As. Et Sa'id ibn Zayd ibn Amr ibn Nufayl, et son épouse Fatima bint Al-Khattab, sœur d'Omar ibn Al-Khattab. Et Umayr ibn Abi Waqqas, et Abd Allah ibn Mas'ud, et son frère Utbah ibn Mas'ud. Et Salit ibn Amr Al-Amiri, et Ayash ibn Abi Rabia Al-Makhzumi, et son épouse Asma bint Salamah ibn Mukharribah At-Tamimiyah. Et Mas'ud ibn Rabia ibn Amr Al-Qari, des Banu Al-Hun ibn Khuzaimah, qui sont Al-Qarah. Et Khunays ibn Hudhafah ibn Qays ibn Adi As-Sahmi. Et Abd Allah ibn Jahsh Al-Asadi.

Pour compléter les premiers à croire au Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui : Ja'far ibn Abi Talib, et son épouse Asma bint Umays. Et Amer ibn Rabia Al-Anazi, des Anz ibn Wail, allié d'Al-Khattab ibn Nufayl. Et Abu Ahmad ibn Jahsh, l'aveugle. Et Hatib ibn Al-Harith ibn Ma'mar Al-Jumahi, et son épouse, la fille de Al-Mujallil Al-Amiriyah. Et Hattab ibn Al-Harith, son frère, et son épouse Fukayhah bint Yasar. Et leur frère Ma'mar ibn Al-Harith ibn Ma'mar Al-Jumahi. Et Al-Muttalib ibn Azhar ibn Abd Awf Az-Zuhri, et son épouse Ramlah bint Abi Awf As-Sahmiyah. Et An-Nahham, dont le nom est Nu'aym ibn Abd Allah Al-Adawi. Et Amer ibn Fuheirah, l'affranchi d'Abu Bakr As-Siddiq. Et Hatib ibn Amr ibn Shams ibn Abd Wudd Al-Amiri, frère de Salit ibn Amr. Et Abu Hudhayfah ibn Utbah ibn Rabia, dont le nom est Hisham ibn Utbah...

title: Ce que les Compagnons ont subi comme tortures de la part des Quraysh.
details: Les premiers à avoir manifesté leur islam furent sept personnes : le Messager d'Allah (que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui), Abu Bakr, Ammar, sa mère Sumayya, Suhayb, Bilal et Al-Miqdad. Quant au Messager d'Allah (que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui), Allah l'a protégé par son oncle Abu Talib. Quant à Abu Bakr, il a été protégé par son peuple. Quant aux autres, les polythéistes les capturèrent, les revêtirent d'armures de fer et les firent rôtir au soleil. Tous cédèrent à leurs exigences, sauf Bilal. En effet, sa vie lui était précieuse pour Allah, le Tout-Puissant, et il était méprisé par son peuple. Ils le prirent, le confièrent aux enfants qui le promenaient dans les vallées de La Mecque, tandis qu'il disait : "Un, Un !". Ils lui attachèrent une corde au cou et le donnèrent aux enfants pour qu'ils jouent avec, jusqu'à ce que cela marque son cou. Bilal appartenait à la tribu de Bani Jumah. Celui qui était le plus cruel dans son supplice était Umayya ibn Khalaf. Il le sortait lorsque la chaleur de midi était intense, le jetait sur le dos dans la plaine de La Mecque, puis ordonnait qu'une énorme roche soit placée sur sa poitrine. Puis il lui disait : "Tu resteras ainsi jusqu'à ce que tu meures ou que tu renies Muhammad et que tu adores Al-Lat et Al-Uzza." Tandis qu'il subissait ce tourment et cette épreuve, il disait : "Un, Un !". Son supplice et son épreuve semblaient accroître sa foi par-dessus sa foi. Abu Bakr fut touché lorsqu'il le vit un jour dans cette extrême humiliation. Il l'acheta et l'affranchit, et avec lui, il affranchit six autres qui étaient torturés pour l'islam.

title: La tribu de Quraysh demanda à Abû Tâlib de retenir le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et la bénédiction soient sur lui.
details: Le Messager d'Allah, que la paix et les bénédictions d'Allah soient sur lui, appelait à Allah le Très-Haut en toutes circonstances ; de nuit comme de jour, en secret comme en public, sans que rien ne le détourne de cela, ni que personne ne le repousse, ni qu'aucun obstacle ne l'en empêche. Il suivait les gens dans leurs assemblées, leurs réunions et leurs cercles, ainsi que lors des saisons et des lieux de rassemblement du pèlerinage ; il appelait quiconque il rencontrait, qu'il soit libre ou esclave, faible ou fort, riche ou pauvre. Les mécréants de sa tribu, les polythéistes de Quraysh, se sont acharnés sur lui et sur ceux qui l'ont suivi.
